reviewText: Brutal Legend combines two of my favourite things in life, Video Games & Metal. This is the game that introduced me to what is now my favourite video game company, Double Fine. In every Double Fine game you can feel the love Tim & the crew shove into every single game they create (did that sound weird?). Brutal Legend puts players in the shoes of Eddie Riggs (preformed by Jack Black) and sends him to a land which is every metal head’s dream. The open world is filled with creatures, buildings, allies and enemies all heavily (see what I did there) inspired by Metal artwork and music throughout the years. To travel through this open world, you get a badass car named the Druid Plow, and this is where the Metal kicks in full gear. The soundtrack is incredible and easily one of best parts of this game, I still hope Double Fine releases a licensed soundtrack that I can throw money at. There is absolutely no way to describe how great it feels to cruise through this Metal world, listening to a flawless and kickass soundtrack.  Without this game, I would’ve never been introduced to one of my now favourite bands, Manowar. The soundtrack includes Rob Zombie, Judas Priest, Scorpions, Tenacious D (of course), and many more fantastic bands. The voice cast is top notch as well, featuring many metal cameos such as Rob Halford and Lemmy but also having great actors such as Jennifer Hale and Tim Curry, you know Double Fine’s voice acting director is good when you can understand every word Lemmy and Ozzy speak. As with all Double Fine games, the dialogue can be very hilarious, the bigger the metal fan you are, the more you will laugh as this is the game is filled with references to the culture. This game received a lot of negative reviews about the gameplay, centering around the RTS aspects, which is funny since the RTS feature was the first part of the game developed. A simple way to describe the gameplay is “God Of War” style with RTS elements. The RTS factor only comes in during boss battles and multiplayer, where you control a large army fighting another while still being in third person rather than the usual RTS top down view. The RTS portions have a bit of a learning curve, but it’s not difficult or tedious, it feels great to lead an army AND fight alongside them. Overall if you are a metal head, Brutal Legend will feel like a game made especially for you. If you aren’t this is still an incredible game, an epic tale filled with adventure, comedy, great characters and decapitations. Brutal Legend is a game you must experience.

reviewText:
Short version: 72%Brütal Legend is awesome and metal. Brütal Legend is also a mediocre and forgettable open world/hack & slash/strategy game. A prime example why Steam needs a “meh” button for the reviews.

Long version:Brütal Legend is a tribute to metal. Not cash-in whiny pop metal, but real, classic, early seventies, head-banging, engine-worshipping, leather-winged heavy metal. It is a temple for bands like Black Sabbath, Judas Priest, or Motörhead– just to name a few from the in-game soundtrack.

This game is so metal that its cast has such names as Jack Black as the protagonist, Rob Halford as the first main boss, and Ozzy Osbourne as the shopkeeper. This game is so metal that the entire landscape is never-ending scenery of heavy metal album covers. This game is probably as metal as metal you can get without dipping your computer in molten steel.

Brütal Legend is also incredibly mediocre. It wants to combine three genres: GTA style open world exploration/driving, hack & slash brawling, and real-time strategy. The problem is that it isn’t remotely good in any of those.
The brawling is dumb, although fun: you mindlessly mash two buttons and hope that the enemy runs out of health faster than you do.
The RTS part consists of spawning an endless stream of units until one army reaches the end of the battlefield to wreck the opponent’s production stage. To be frank, it is downright boring.
Still, the driving takes the cake. The controls are worse than you can imagine (worse than Borderlands could ever be), and when you have to race on narrow platforms over bottomless pits… get yourself a pack of Xanax.

I wouldn’t call Brütal Legend bad… the soundtrack and most of the plot about leading a metal-fuelled revolution against the demon-like oppressors can easily entertain you from start to finish, but you will always have the feeling that the game mechanics could have been a lot better.

reviewText:
What do you do when you are on the game’s store page? You buy it, install it and play it. Once you initiate the third process, you won’t need convincing on keeping on doing it.  The game is entertaining, detailed even where you don’t expect it, the npc’s are loveable, the open world big enough to lose yourself in it. What was a surprise that made me skeptic at first but turned out to be another enjoyable feature was the “casual” RTS, where from the protagonists third person that turns into a flying demon you command your various troops to take out towers and ultimately, the stage, by implementing your tactics. I wasn’t a fan of metal when I started playing this game, but because of it, I have all the metal songs from this game in my playlist.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=382331717

You are Eddie Riggs, the best roadie in the world, which means you are the one responsible for the stage glamour, but no one will know it. As things get out of control, you find your way into the past, into the age of metal, where people are used against their will by a tyrant which servers Doviculus, the demon responsible for the taint that corrupts all what metal stands for. Since Eddie is good at making things work and gives people purpose, a revolution is started. There will be many great characters that you’ll meet along the way, many of which are based on real life metal stars.  There is always a romantic sub plot where you might find some clichés, but they are the best kind. Since the story takes place in an open world, you can expect a lot of variation in locations and types of allies and enemies.

There are a lot of sidequests and neither are the fetch types, more like ambushing, hunting, racing, keeping the bikers away while a headbanger charms a girl, shooting from a ramped car, placing markers for the guy with no aim to shoot rockets, that sort of stuff. Once I had to clear a cave so that a family of bats could go back in, which earned me kisses and an apology from a bat for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on my head. There are solos to find, serpents to free and legends to learn. It’s the kind of open world that never fills empty.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=382331029
In the RTS missions, you’ll use your solos and your cunning, for doing things like melting your enemies faces and send the invisible forces to attack the stage while the shooters and the pyromans defend your stage.  The Deuce(your car) is fun to drive, but the controls may prove to be difficult at first, which makes it even more fun.  You can raise relics, which include Motorfoges, where you will  upgrade your attack, the Deuce, change outfits, enhance your weapons and buy stones to place on a mountain.
If you’re a fan of the RTS system in the game, you can expect a good time in the multiplayer.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=382329151
I found many of my favorite gaming moments here. While people find some faults in this game, everyone finds the way to play this game and others don’t recognize those faults at all. The end was emotional satisfying, sneaking away, yet finding yourself surrounded by friends that simply ask you to never forget them at which point you’d likely say that you won’t, then driving into the sunset while your girlfriend watches smiling and dropping a tear.  You can free roam afterwards to see what more this game has to offer. I’m not done with it and I don’t want to, not until I hear of a sequel at least. In the end, I find Brütal Legend to do everything right.

reviewText:
So I felt it is time for me to make a review of one of my personal favorite games of all time and too post why and the problems i have with the game. Possibly some hope in here that they make another too kick even more metal ♥♥♥.

In the vast lands of Brütal Legend made from the metal bones of Ormagöden the firey metal god. You are the man to change it all but take none of the credit you are the Roadie. Born in a wrong time this roadie knew he was meant (destined even) for something better, something Metal and Full of Gore. Venture through a land built of every punk teen's wet dream and true man's vision.

The Pros:
- It's got a Metal as ♥♥♥♥ of story worth playing experiencing fight demons, slay the puss, and of course ROCK
- A great wide landscape to venture through slaying all those who oppose you in your conquest
- You Weild an Axe and guitar with far more powers than you and I can comprehend with plenty of other powers found along your journey
- The land vast and all has plenty of quests to rock you some upgrades found in the motor forge
- A great lore (in my opinion) that can be greatly expanded on and just enjoy
- The God damn soundtrack is Bloody EPIC to put softly full of rocking tunes for you to rock out to on your journey
- JACK BLACK!!!!!! nuf said
- The strategy aspect is well done providing a differing touch on the game to make it a unique experience

The Cons:
- The multiplayer is kind of just a port of the game's strategy which is nice just not that boom your looking for counting no one plays it i know of
- the strategy aspect all though well done just feels like an unecessary element put in the game and that kind of sucks

Honestly those are the only cons i can think of. I'm sure you will think of plenty if its not your cup of tea but to me this is my mona lisa, MY masterpiece. No matter how you look at it though it is a good buy, plenty of hours ahead of banging your head and your mom yelling at you that its too violent. Hope you enjoy and please leave your hate down below I always love reading stupidity. :^)

reviewText:
I played this game for a few hrs, and I was not feeling. I was confused when i got to the part where you had to battle by recruiting units,  and gain fans to upgrade your stage. So i mostly just roamed around completing side missions and gather the collectables until I stopped  playing.

A few months went by and decided to give the game another shot. I started from scratch to go back and see if this time I understood the battle mechanics a bit better. 2nd time was the charm, I had a better understanding of the battle system and started to enjoy the game a lot more. After that i was way more into the game. It made me want to complete the game and do all the achievements (Because i am lame like that)

Very nice game. Good music, good story, very likeable characters. The side missions do get a bit boring because they are repetative and not really that challenging (Even on Brutal difficulty)

You'll finish the game pretty quickly if you don't bother looking for collectables or do the side missions. You aren't missing much if you just go right through the story, although the racing and animal hunting side missions have some funny dialogue.

reviewText:
Brütal Legend is a game for metalheads.  Yoü play metal, yoü listen to metal, yoü ARE the metal.  I don't think any other game has managed to so completely immerse the player in a concept and create süch a rich game world.  The art direction at Doüble Fine is simply amazing.

The game itself is rather üniqüe, combining an open world third-person action game with real time strategy.  Ünfortünately düring the original release, EA's advertising glossed over the RTS aspect, leading many players who were expecting a straight action game to be confüsed and disappointed.  Controlling troops from a third-person perspective may not be as flexible as a normal RTS and it does take some getting üsed to, büt it works well for what its intended for in the game.

The müsic in the game and the long list of big name voice actors really help draw yoü into the game.  Even thoügh I don't particülarly like most of the bands that are featüred in the game, the müsic fits so well that I can enjoy it anyway.  Brütal Legend even has the most perfectly placed song I've ever heard in a game düring one of the cütscenes, thoügh I can't stand listening to it oütside the game.

One problem some people may have is that Jack Black plays the main character.  I can assüre yoü that it is not a problem.  Eddie Rigg's character is Jack Black playing Jack Black, büt written by Doüble Fine so there is none of Jack Black's classic stüpidity.  Ünless yoü cringe at the soünd of Jack Black's voice, I think yoü'll be able to enjoy the game jüst fine.

My only disappointments are that the story felt like it ended rather süddenly when I thoüght it was only halfway throügh, the side missions get rather repetitive, and Doüble Fine doesn't have the fünds to make a seqüel.  Hopefülly that will come in the fütüre.

To süm üp: play this game!  Everyone needs more metal in their lives.

reviewText:
Brutal Legend is a mash up of a couple different genres, Action Adventure Open World RTS...yes, that many...

I'll start out with the graphics, it is a nice art style however the graphics really show the three years difference, even on higher resolutions the game doesn't look as crisp as others. There is hardly any customization in the options menu to try get a bit more beef out the graphics which is almost a must for PC ports.

The actual game play is nicely done though, as I said to begin with, there are four different genres mashed up here, Action Adventure is done very well, the hack and slash mechanics are basic, but the addition of guitar solos brings a whole new way of playing, allowing you to buff up your characters or deal damage to your foes.  The open world aspect is also done very well, the world seems huge, there are plenty of side quests to keep you busy throughout the story, however these aren't crucial for story or game progress elements, and they are purely there as additional things to do.  Finally, the RTS element, throughout the course of the game, you will take part in a number of grand scale battles, in which you have to manage your resources (fans in this case) and build an army in which you command using basic squad game controls, so follow, defend and attack. To me this seemed like the worst of the four though, it seemed a little clunky and out of place, I would much rather have played it without the strategy side.

The sound track and music in Brutal Legend is obviously going to be amazing. The game features 107 metal tracks from 75 different bands, ranging from Motörhead, Ozzy Osbourne, Kiss to Tenacious D as well as many more.  The main character is also voiced and based on Jack Black which also adds the comical side of things in too.

There isn't much difficulty in playing Brutal Legends, as long as you get to grips with the basics of the RTS elements, you won't find yourself having too many issues. The hack and slash parts are too easy at times, so the only challenge comes from the RTS, which is a shame, because I would of liked to have got a little more stuck into the combat and maybe the addition of extra combos.

The game length is very respectable, I normally try to complete as many of the side missions I can in these types of games, so it took me almost thirty five hours to complete it fully, so it is a pretty chunky game, time wise.

I had a few minor technical issues, even though the game was running at a smooth 60 fps most of the time, it almost felt as if I was still playing at 30, not sure whether that was an issue with my rig or not though, I turned on v-sync and that seemed to make a little better, but not by much. I also wanted to play in windowed mode for a while because I had the wiki page open on my second screen, and this gave me numerous issues with the cursor in game, I would all of a sudden just get my desktop background because my mouse had wandered off screen into my task bar, or I would start to get hover-over tooltips for other shortcuts on my windows task bar randomly, all small issues that could of quite easily of been fixed.

My final recommendation for Brutal Legend is definitely give it a try, it might not be everyone's cup of tea, but I did have a lot of fun playing it, I mean, I did plunge thirty five hours of my life playing it...there is plenty of content and even just the sound track is worth some of your time, you can get the game at regular price for £10,99, but expect this to drop to as low as £2 in sales, and then you have yourself a real bargain.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

One of the coolest games around. Brutal Legend combines Heavy Metal, Rock, Hack and Slash and RTS all in a massive and gorgeous apocalyptic open world.

reviewText:
A bit about the game and developers.

Brütal Legend is an action game developed by Double Fine studios. They are the same studio that made The Cave (amazing game!), Iron Brigade, Stacking, Costume Quest, Psychonauts and couple of more others. I should mention that Brütal Legend also has couple of very good rock artists. Jack Black and Ozzy Osbourn. Honestly, I love to listen to rock-metal, but I ain't fan of Ozzy's music, and I've heard a lot of better artists than Jack, but Jack is definitely one of my favorite actors. I mean, that guy is funny! And he's an amazing voice actor in this game!

About Gameplay.
Brütal Legend is an action game in which all you do is hit, slash, run over and burn your enemies. Now, a lot of people find this type of game very amusing, but to me that's just too simple. Luckily, this game comes with another approach, that suits me a bit better! A strategy one! You are able to take the game into a semi-top down view, build your units and send them to where ever you'd like them to go. But I'll talk more about that later!

So, in Brütal Legend you play as a roadie (sorry if I misspelled it!) who died on a stage. The roadie, Eddie, gets brought back to life by the power of Ormagöden. But he got back into a Heavy Metal world, not the normal one. In that world, your job is to fight demons, and goths, using nothing but the power of true rock!

When it comes to fighting, controls are quite easy to master. Managing an army is a bit harder, but still quite easy to remember and use in combat. And remember, 10 is always better than 1. So use those units wisely! In the game there are various relics that you can find. Some give you special powers, and others lets you resurrect a metal shop". Inside of it you find Guardian of Metal (Ozzy!)

Awesome game if you enjoy an extensive world to explore and a crazy amount of silliness~

reviewText:
Brutal Legend is an open world hack n' slash staring Jack Black as Eddie Riggs, set in a fantasy world of a heavy metal album cover come to life. I felt captivated by the story from start to finish, more than I enjoyed the game and its pretty rare for me to say such a thing. As a game, the combat was just there, other games do it better, but nothing does the unique atmosphere better than Brutal Legend.

The story is simple, you're a downtrodden roadie working for an ungrateful emo band that costs you your life. From there, you're transported to a fantastic land made of metal and stone. Where mammoths have chrome tusks and spiders made of steel. Its a fresh take on any fantasy world. Nighttime turns into a gorgeous meteorological phenomenon, either with electric blue moons or asteroid showers. The land is getting oppressed by a demon lord and you need to band together, gather troops and lead an uprising to defeat him!

The characters are straight out of the late 70s early 80s heavy metal scene. Everyone is wearing spikes and black. Men have big muscles, washboard abs, long flowing hair and the ladies are always petite with enough mascara to blot out the sun. All the characters have big eyes and I think that helps them convey emotion much better. Its a wonderfully acted game, from the voice acting to the animations.

There's a lot of humor, charm and goofiness that I enjoyed. I'm not one that likes comedy in games, but it hit the mark for me. Its not all comedy, the game takes itself serious when it has to be. The cameos also helped. Seeing Lemmy from Motorhead as my healer throughout the game. Having Ozzy Osbourne upgrade my car's weapons was a lot of fun. Tim Curry as the supreme villain. With all the famous voices incredible performances, there were plenty of great lesser known talent doing a fantastic job voice acting. All the characters no matter how big or small all have personality and charm, even if none of them have last names.

Halfway through the game, the emo starts to bleed into this world of metal and the new characters are all gothed up. Crazy haired kids" with striped shirts

reviewText:
Brütal Legend has everything going for it, a cool world inspired by Metal and  Hard Rock albums, fun characters with really fun dialouge, and an excellent soundtrack.
Then the gameplay comes in and ruins it all.

The basic hack and slash gameplay is honestly fine, it's nothing special but works, the car customizing is pretty good and I enjoy driving around the world in my pimped out Metal car.

But it's when the infamous RTS segements comes in, they are just plain horrible, they are clunky to control and offer zero tactics, all you can do is spam out enemies and bombrush them at the enemy, the worst part is that the RTS segements becomes the main thing in this game, and that ruined the whole game for me.

If you can overcome the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ RTS segements and controls then there is a fun game for you here, but for me this is easily the worst game made from Tim Schafer and Double Fine, and if they ever revisits this series I hope they either greatly improves on the RTS mechanics or just scrap them all together.

Edit: This is no longer the worst game made by Double Fine since they went and made Spacebase DF9 and Broken Age, so count yourself lucky Brutal Legend

reviewText:
Brutal Legend is a third person action-adventure game which features a vast open world with a variety of terrain. Voice actors include Jack Black and heavy mtetal music icons.

Double-Fine is known for some great games such as Grim Fandango, Costume Quest, and a vast array of others. This game is no exception to the charm that Double Fine Productions is known for, and expands on that with a large world for you to explore - something not often found in other Double Fine projects despite their games' colorful personalities.

Jack Black stars as Eddie Riggs, a roadie for a band. You guide Eddie Rigs in a dangerous land while making a few friends and building a ride along the way. Cameos include Ozzie Osbourne, David Bowie, David Mustane and more, doing stellar voice acting for this action filled adventure.

It's hard to put the game down, the game seems to blend genres together very well from racing to beat-em-up to real time strategy, all these elements are mixed in at one time or another to break the repetition and it's successfully done so.

Pros Cleverly written storyline with legnth to match
Jack Black's humor will brighten anyone's day
Great game design from mechanics to combat, everything is engaging
Awesome soundtrack
Full controller support
Mutiplayer battles
Cons Low Difficulty, might be a tad too easy for the hardcore gamer
Limited graphics option
A full Co-Op campaign would have been perfect for this game
Limited to 1080p
Forcing 4x AA and above can/will cause game to have missing textures
Final thoughts:
I highly recommend this game to you whether you are a fan of Jack Black's movies or action gaming with attitude and flair. This has 80's hair metal written all over it and it shows. I wish we could get a sequel!

Rating (8.6 out of 10)

This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

reviewText:
Heavy metal, women, more heavy metal, gore, battles, booze. your guitar shoots electricity and can summon a giant burning zepelin to crush them demons, summon your all migthy beast (car or animal) and ride them, f**king enemies up, more heavy metal, wield an axe that you may upgrade (with the rest of the stuff) to be a holy soul eating fu**, more heavy metal, swearing, teach the future chick who will kill you to french kiss, did i mention heavy metal?

PROS:

-SOUNDTRACK: Great soundtrack(the heavy metal songs and the overworld ones, very relaxing), actually a lot of ppl listens to heavy metal because of this game( like me)

-VOICE ACTING: Fu**ing great! It has JB( Jack black, Leader of the band Tenacious D with Kyle, actor in films like King Kong 2005 , The Pick of Destiny and voice actor of Kung Fu Panda, as Po) as Eddie Riggs, Kyle Gas( partner of Jack black) as the Cannoner and the random bat dad guy, Ozzy Osbrown( or something) as the keeper of secrets, Lemmy Kilmister as Kill Master, etc...

-GAMEPLAY: Good hack-n-slash game with an axe to hack and a guitar to shoot electricity because that rocks! You may summon your car (druidplower) and ♥♥♥♥ your enemies. The main missions are good, but a good propotion of them is to escort the Tour bus with your car and the battle Stages, that i will talk later. The side missions are also good, but some repetitive. There are the Ambush, Race, Hunting record and Cannon defence + the unique ones, but of there are only one each.

-COLLECTIBLES: Yes, there are dragons to free, with the gods of metal reward you with tribute and for every 10 dragons a upgrade (Health, regen, etc), Legends, to look the past and how was everything created, artwork, the Metal Songs, that add more songs to your soundtrack. and fairies, that give you tribute if you catch them.

-METAL FORGE: It is were you go and purchase upgrades for your car, axe and guitar + paintjobs(for the druidplower or your jacket), purchase cool moves and get some statues + Ozzy is in there...yes...

-STORY: The story is amazing, simple, but amazing, with a very good twist at the end( after the secondlast battle), tho it leaves you wanting a Brütal Legend 2( tho i doubt there will be).It is a 10-15 hour game, at least for me.

DLC( included in the game and only in the PC version): Adds some skins for Eddie Riggs, your car, axe, guitar, and statues+ 1 new weapon and a new ram for your car+ an eye that points you in the direction of a collectible, helps a lot.

CONS:
-GAMEPLAY: There's another part of the gameplay, it is the RTS one. In the Stages( battles) you can create units by getting fans from merchandise booths in fan gysers, and basicly your objective is to destroy the enemy Stage. It feels like it is out of place fot this type of game, but it is fun non-the less, gets repititive tho.

-MULTIPLAYER is dead, tho there are those 2 random persons from the forum who decided to do some achivements, the multiplayer is dead, tho it doesn't suprise me, as it is only the RTS part of the game, and as i said, it is out of place for this type of game and has a rly poor ranking that it also feels out of place. Only good thing is that it let's you try the other 2 factions (Tainted coil, my favourite, and the other one).

-BUGS: Yes, there are bugs, not a lot of them, but some, some haves you stuck between invisible walls.

-DIFFICULTY: It is easy even on Brütal( Tho the final Stage battle took me 3 tries, and with them i found the trick to beat it). Ofc you will need to get upgrades for your axe, guitar( tho for the final hours of gameplay you should have it upgraded to the max upgrade) and the Dragons for health upgrades and whatnot( if you don't get those ofc it will be hard).


Conclusion: Heavy metal will never die, 9/10.

reviewText:
Fan of metal music? Rock music? BOTH? Well you're in luck! This game combines these genres, in their widest and most well-selected form (107 songs from 75 bands, aside from the game's own soundtrack), with a fantastic game based around the world of rock and metal music!

reviewText:
Brutal Legend is.... Fun + Metal in one wrapper that doesn't take itself seriously.
This is both good and bad. Bad in that it wants to combine open world exploration, hack & slash, RPG, driving, and some odd strategy layer. The problem is that it isn’t GOOD at anything. This game isn't innovative or original in terms of game mechanics, and the controls vary between clunky and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ depending on what you are doing. On the flip side, the game doesn't try to do anything but be fun and humorous. The plot is funny as hell and the character models, script, even the landscape refuse to even try being serious. Which becomes awkward because combat can become painfully difficult at odd times.

As for being metal, this game will ring so true to that concept it becomes impossible to conceive of something that could do a better job. The music, the customization options, character models, landscape, everything hearkens back to the era of real heavy metal. I mean, hell King LionWhyte" has so much "big hair" that it would have made Dee Snider jealous in the 80s and he uses it to fly! lol :)

Honestly I'd say this game was built on "Sex

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Brütal Legend is an action, hack and slash game that pulls to the hard rock or metal stereotype subculture. I personally enjoyed one play through for the game.
Imagine a world that heavy metal music describes… Skulls, demons, fire, explosions, and hot girls… Brutal legend projects those images into a video game (and quite accurately I might add). Unfortunately that doesn’t necessarily mean the combat in the game was transferred so well, I felt like I was grinding a lot to get through the game. There wasn’t a very fluid sense of progression in the game, and at times I was just trying to count down how many more enemies I’d need to decapitate before the game would be complete.
I don’t recommend this game for anyone except people that really like metal music and metal themes (So that you may be revitalized from the combat by listening to excellent music!). As a note about the humor; the humor in the game is quite good which should be expected since Jack Black is voicing the main character and Ozzy Osbourne’s mumbling just got me to smile every time.
-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  You play as the main character “Eddie”, a roadie. I don’t want to get into too much detail because the story was my favorite part of this game, and giving away any of it would take away from your enjoyment if you actually get the game. I’ll just say that the story was pretty good, it didn’t always make logical sense (*cough cough* Legends that I found *cough cough* ), but in the end it was presented very well.

Game Play: This is where the game takes the biggest hit, the combat gets old really fast you have a choice between using electric lightning and death, or beating people to death with an axe. Regardless of the fighting style or the weapon you prefer, you will hack your way through (literally) the hoards of hell.
It would be nice if they dropped orb, experience points, gold/money, or gave some sort of gain. Ultimately you will get nothing for murdering them. Why murder them? Because if you don’t; they’ll murder you, or your friends and you’ll fail the quest.
Additionally the game switches to a “command and conquer” style at various points, and that’s actually where I found myself enjoying the game. Maybe it’s because they let me have wings… I am a sucker for wings… Anyway, you direct your troops and destroy your enemy’s stage. That does get old but it’s more of a strategy game at that point; and I like strategy games.

Multi-player:  The online Multiplayer community is kind of dead; not that I can blame it. All you can do for multiplayer is the battles, so directing your troops against someone else’s. I need some of the achievements for multiplayer that I can’t get against the AI on offline mode, so I posted on the forums and hopefully will get a majority of them completed… but I’m not holding my breath; the achievements don’t strike me as very… swift.

Achievements: Simple break down for achievements: 1) Achievements for beating the game 2) Achievements for doing all the things in the open world 3) Achievements you get for doing Battles and playing against other human players 4) Achievements you get for beating the game again [on harder difficulties and getting things you didn’t notice or need to restart to do]
My response to these achievements is mostly apathetic; I wasn’t impressed and was just looking forward to finishing as much as possible so I could play something that I enjoyed.

Price: The price for Brütal Legend is $14.99, I plugged 27 hours into the game, with an intent to play through a few more times (so I expect the game to make it to about 35-40 hours), that’s a fair price for the time, however I didn’t find myself enjoying the game, unless you know you like games like this you should probably put your money into a game that will give better satisfaction.
Actually I would prefer to buy the soundtrack as a standalone instead of the game itself. Currently (summer 2014 steam sale) the game is on sale, if you’re really itching for a new game and you think you might like this one, go for it that’s a fair price in my book.

Conclusion:Pro’s: I enjoyed the story, the music is great, I understood the subculture humor and references, Jack Black, Ozzy Osbourne.
Con’s: The combat is grindy and boring, I really hate driving cars (this game forced me learn how to do use it effectively though…), low sense of progression.
It’s annoying that I need to either recommend or not recommend the game because to by honest my opinion falls right in-between both of them. I’m not recommending though just because the game was so grindy.
Once again though, if you meet the following description you should overrule my opinion and try it out yourself: A) You like Metal Music, B) You like hack and Slash Games, C) You don’t care about achievements, D) You’re not a perfectionist for world completion, E) You want a game to play for about 10-20 hours.

reviewText:
Graphics: Despite being a game that's almost 7 years old, they still hold up and look great. The design of the characters, vehicles, weapons and the surround world all fit perfectly together. Great effects throughout.

Soundtrack:  In my opinion, it's the best video game soundtrack ever. Over 100 different songs from 75 bands (according to Wikipedia) in all different subgenres of metal. It's just fantastic.

Controls: I played the game using an Xbox controller and found the controls very easy and intuitive. Whether it's fighting or commanding troops, the control scheme is easy and doesn't require a lot of unnecessary movement. The only issue I had was sometimes during battle I couldn't pull up my song list unless I hit the RT button multiple times in a row.

Gameplay: The game was not quite what I expected. I thought this was going to be an action-adventure game where you solely control Eddie and fight with him. That's partly true. I did not realize the RTS-like elements of controlling and directing your crew throughout the game. It works well and is quite enjoyable, I just didn't realize it was part of the game. I will say that at times the combat feels repetitive and the RTS parts of the game all feel identical for the most part, but never to the point that it becomes unenjoyable.

Story: The voice acting in this game is incredible. All of the actors do a fantastic job, especially Jack Black. The story is fun and has a few twists and turns that keep you guessing. I really enjoyed all of the different characters introduced throughout the game, especially the metal legends.

I would say this is an absolute must play game if you're a fan of metal, but even if you're not I would still highly recommend it. It's another fantastic example of what makes Double Fine such a great studio.

reviewText:
In Sum: Awesome soundtrack and voice performances, mostly fun gameplay with some odd controls and a poorly-realized RTS system tacked on.  The coolness overcomes the flaws mostly. 4.2/5

-----

Jack Black.  Ozzy Osbourne.  Lemmy.  Rob Halford.  If those names mean anything to you, then you know why you have to play this game.  You'll know what you're in for when you see the opening scene.

Brutal Legend is a Heavy Metal fantasy game made by Tim Schafer, creator of classics like Full Throttle and Psychonauts.

The game takes place in a fantasy world inspired by metal albums, with many references to metal bands and of course, one of the best soundtracks ever put in a game.  The music alone is like a primer on heavy metal.

The story follows a roadie named Eddie Riggs, who is frustrated by the state of modern music.  The band he's touring with sucks and sounds more like a boy band than rockers.  When their stupid antics result in an accident that kills the roadie, he wakes up in a horrific-but-awesome other world, a world where rock and roll has actual power.

There is an interesting plot with some fascinating characters along the way.  The game is worth it for the performances.  Jack Black plays Eddie, while his Tenacious D partner Kyle Gass has a small role.  Ozzy, Lita Ford, and Lemmy have important roles, as well, but the biggest performances are provided by Judas Priest's Rob Halford and Tim Curry.  Veteran gaming actress Jennifer Hale also does a great role here.

The world never becomes fully realistic due to its fantastical nature, but it never stops being awesome.  This is a game where you can go to a Stonehenge made out of swords, play a guitar riff to summon a Deuce, then drive over to a clone of Mt Rushmore with Ozzy's head while listening to awesome music.

The gameplay itself has some issue, and part of the issue is that the game merges several genres, and not all that well.  The camera is unreliable, for one thing.  But the biggest issue is that the game starts out as an action game, then turns into a odd perspective on an RTS.

That's right, the game is a real-time strategy except instead of being top down, it's viewed from behind a character.  The game also borrows a bit from Guitar Hero and to a smaller extent, RPGs.  At times, it plays like a GTA-style game.  It is a fusion of many different gaming styles, but they don't really fit together.  The RTS system is especially frustrating.

It really is a case of a game's world and immersion compensating for flawed design.  But the greatness of the game in the end makes up for the problems, and it's a great game to play through.

reviewText:
Damn, I would love to love this game. Seriously. The music kicks ♥♥♥. Jack Black kicks ♥♥♥. The visuals are stunning - as if they'd built the whole game using every single rock and metal album cover and made the world out of it.

However mechanics-wise, it's terrible. The game begins as a sub-par-to-decent third person brawler (with a guitar as a ranged weapon, brilliant!). But somewhere along the line, it becomes some kind of a racing sim. Huh, ok. And then it settles on being a kind of RTS, and a terrible one at that. You need to physically move your character near the units you need to move and there's no visual cue whatsoever to tell you what units, exactly, will be affected by your commands, meaning you end up selecting either too few, or too many.

That game had a LOT of potential but it's the designer team had too many cool ideas and ended up implementing none of them properly.

reviewText:
If you´re looking for a metal game with good storyline and soundtrack, Brutal Legend is for you.
Eddie, the main hero, is a roadie. He takes care of stage of a band he works for. He is disgusted about the band, they doesn´t sing metal,as he says. One day, he wakes up in a different world. In a world of his dreams. Local people are occupated by demons and Eddie helps them to liberate themselves. In game, you´ll meet characters like Guardian of Metal, who is made by Ozzy Osbourne, or Killmaster, who is made by Lemmi Kilmister. There are funny moments, lots of plot-twists and the ending made me cry. That was about the story. The gameplay is trully good, Eddie can use his axe or guitar, he can ride his metal car and play guitar solos, which helps him in combat. The story is quite short, but the secondary quests makes the game much longer.

8/10

reviewText:
The game is funny, has a great voice cast (including metal legends Ozzy Osbourne and Lemmy Kilmister) and has a great soundtrack (even though I'm not that much of a metal fan).

So, why do I not recommend it?
The fighting and driving are ok, nothing to write home about, but I can live with that.
What I can't live with are the RTS mechanics.
I'm not a RTS fan, so that obviously is a factor here, but even so I could have managed, if the mechanics weren't as lacking as they are.
The game is fun until you get thrown into one RTS battle after another, which I just hated and which is the sole reason why I stopped and most likely never will continue.

If you don't mind the RTS parts of the game: GET IT! It's a good game in all parts but the RTS.

reviewText:
Not a fan of metal music? This game will make you one. Brütal Legend is an open world action adventure strategy game with melee combat and RPG elements all rolled into one. You play Eddie Riggs, a roadie transported into a metal world divided by war. When I say metal world, I mean metal world. Everything from creature and character design to the smallest of details is in some way inspired by heavy metal music. The best part about it is that you don't have to be a fan of the genre to appreciate the world and just have a good time mowing down everything you can with the Druid Plow, while listening to over 100 licensed metal tunes, of course.

Combat is centered around two weapons; an axe for melee and guitar for ranged combat. Both can be upgraded with cosmetic and weapon effect changes. Vehicular combat is also present with multiple possibilities ranging from the classic minigun mount to minelaying.

I can't say that the RTS elements work in its favor however, I feel the game would have been better off without. There's not enough depth in the strategic battles where Eddie sprouts wings, controls unit spawning and sending them into battle. Compared to the fast action paced face melting combos you were doing less than a minute ago, the slow RTS battles feel tedious and boring.

The characters all feel unique and genuine in their own way, the story feels right even though it may be just a little bit generic. The main quest line is fun to follow trough but side quests can get repetitive, mostly consisting of ambushes and the occasional defense against 5 waves of attackers. These are just bad attempts at prolonging the experience offered by the game.

Overall this is a terrific game set in an cool world with an awesome soundtrack. It has its small little problems, but the goods far outweigh them. There's about 15 hours of gameplay here to complete everything there is to offer and to top it off a multiplayer mode that matches you against other players in RTS battles.

reviewText:
This game has everything a metal enthusiast's heart desires, but it doesn't stop there. From the trailers I have seen back when it came out in 2009 I expected a funny, metal infused comedy put into a videogame, but I got so much more than that.

You would think that Jack Black and the all-star cast of voice actors is enough to sell the game but nuh-uh, there's more. The hilarious, epic and sometimes cheesy story works on so many levels if you ever had long hair, wore band shirts and maybe branched out to some make-up for the ultimate concert look. I never knew you could build up such a perfect metaphor for all the scenes and subgenres of Metal, yet it's no caricature and can stand perfectly on its own as a serious, comedic approach to the world of Metal music.

Your ears will be spoiled with a fine selection of shredding guitars from Classic Rock over Hair Metal to Black Metal. In the first hours into the game I thought it was all about Classic and Glam Rock, but when I heard Carcass pop up I creamed my jeans and will definitely go through my old records, since my mouth is watering for Metal again!

This game left me stunned after it ended and this is probably the only downside of it.
It has an end.

10 out of 10 metal horns!

reviewText:
Legendary roadie, Eddie Riggs (Jack Black), has an accident at a gig and wakes up in Heavy Metal-land. Which sucks because Heavy Metal-land is under the oppressive ruler-ship of the ultimate poser, Whitesnake!...or somebody. Eddie teams-up with Lars to lead the headbangers to freedom. Let's Rock! (Or we could just drive around, see the sites and listen to some music.)

I have a very limited interest in Heavy Metal, So that aspect can only bring me so far. The world that is created and it's backstory are quite good and the various characters are fun as well. The story would be right at home on contemporary movie screens.

The main missions are mostly over-the-shoulder RTS type battles. I found these battles to be kind of hard and not very fun. Until I stopped trying to play them like an RTS, then they just weren't so hard. I avoided playing them for as long as possible by doing other stuff. There are collectables to be found, Jumps to make and side missions to do. Unfortunately there are only 5 different kinds of side missions; Hunting, Racing and 3 types of fighting. So not much variety there.  I even went after achievements to delay having to play a stage battle.

I went with a mouse+keyboard+controller scheme. For me, Walking around and fighting will almost always be m+k and I much prefer a controller for driving (and of course playing solos). This made things a little messy as I had to relearn some things depending on what I was using. But I got it down for the last couple of battles.

Interesting concept and groundwork, But not much else. A marginal recommendation.

reviewText: Brutal Legend is better than it’s ever been, both as a single-player open-world game unlike any you’ve ever played and as one of the best unique takes on real-time strategy.It’s like a frantic, crazy rock festival: you might have lost your shoes, you might have fuzzy recollections of vomiting, but you can’t wait to go back right in, as soon as possible. That’s what Brutal Legend’s all about. The characters are lovable and the soundtrack is simply phenomenal.If only the developers had had the strength to break free from their original vision and concentrate on what's really good in Brütal Legend. A lot fewer stage battles and a lot more reckless driving and action-packed smashing of heads. In any case, this title is an absolute must-have for anyone who can tolerate the curious RTS design decisions.

reviewText:
Gameplay-wise it's not exceptional - average, really -  and I found the story mode rather short.
However, the game makes up for that in other ways.

It's a game where a hot-rod built by titans races a taxi driven by a demon in a field of exhaust pipe cacti.
It's a game where half-naked amazons ride fire-breathing sabertooth gorillas into battle against gangs of emo zombies.
It's a game where you play literally face-melting riffs against a spider composed of chromed engine parts.

It's a game where every scene and landscape looks like it belongs on the cover of a 70s or 80s heavy metal album, the story feels like it came from the song lyrics of said album, roadies are ninjas (it makes sense in the context), and there are cliffs built out of giant loudpeakers.

Yes, it's that kind of game - set in a delightfully insane world, full of tongue-in-cheek humor, quirky characters, and (how else) plenty of METAL.

It's the most f***ing metal game you'll ever play, and you'll love every minute of it.

Bring on the impalement!

reviewText:
I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

One Hour Reviews #30: Brutal Legend

Brutal Legend is an unapologetic love letter to hard rock and heavy metal music.  If you are a fan of this kind of music, that alone is enough for me to recommend this game.  But as it happens, Brutal Legend also happens to be pretty fun.

The story in Brutal Legend is pretty damn silly.  It's not meant to be taken seriously.  But if tongue-in-cheek humor is not what you are looking for, then you should look elsewhere because Brutal Legend brings it in spades.

The gameplay is a mix of combat and exploration.  The beginning is fairly combat heavy, but as I wrapped up my first hour of play I started to get a sense for more of an open world feel to the game.  Combat itself is fast paced.  You start with a huge axe for melee attacks, but you also get a guitar which shoots lightning (don't ask, just go with it).  But the game will also build on these basic attacks and unlock combination attacks and guitar solos".

Along with the combat and exploration

reviewText:
A total gem by one of gaming's master humorists: Tim Schafer.

The game is nearly flawless with the only complaint I have being that there isn't MORE of it!

An excellent soundtrack that will please both Heavy Metal diehards as well as newcomers to the musical genre. It serves as an easy intro to a musical scene that might otherwise prove exclusionary to those who don't immediately get it". Trust me by the end of this game
date:
and probably long before you will understand what Heavy Metal is all about.

Tim Schafer is able to bring the more humorous and satirical elements of the musical genre to the forefront without once compromising it's soul. Let's examine closer though the actual game and it's facets:

GAMEPLAY: While the bulk of the game is played as an action-adventure
recommended: there is a noticeable portion that is a real-time strategy meta-game
hoursPlayed: which has thrown some people off. Luckily one game-mode compliments the other and if you play around with it you should succeed.\n\nThe main action-adventure portions has you controlling the main character
voteText: Eddie Riggs
helpfulPercent: as he uses a battle axe to cleave through enemies
votesHelpful: and a guitar that allows you to perform magical attacks and perform short "solos" which are quick time rythymn events to unlock special moves or summon a hot rod you can use to zip across the very large landscape.  You can upgrade your various weapons and hot rod by collecting fire tributes through various missions in underground garages. This has every aspect of an action adventure game you could possibly want
votesTotal: a HUGE open world
votesFunny: side missions
commentsCount: collectables that unlock new songs and background story
column16: and lots of enemies to fight.\n\nThe real-time strategy missions utilize a similar control scheme but focuses you more on controlling large groups of your army you recruit. The gimmick is a little confusing at first and involves building merch booths on fan geysers to collect enough points to purchase more units to send into battle
column17: but once you get the hang of it becomes quite enjoyable and rather intense. Aside from the army control
column18: Eddie can also use his guitar solos to buff his soldiers or do combo-attacks with each of the select unit types for special damage. The units include Headbangers (Infantry)
column19: Razor Girls (Ranged)
column24: Fire Barons (Anti-Infantry Vehicle) Metal Beasts (Short Range Anti-Infantry)
column25:
and Rock Crusher (Ranged Assault Vehicle) all of which have a double-team ability with Eddie.


GRAPHICS: The game just looks great
column26: it doesn't go for super realistic but has a very stylized look that at all times makes you think of Heavy Metal Album covers. The design of the world is deliberately gothic and looks like if H.R. Giger did paints of Norse Mythology. The skyscapes look breathtaking and the world is chock full of delicious eye candy that makes you just stop and take it all in. Truly exceptional!\n\nMUSIC: There's not much more to say
column27: this is a Metalhead's wet dream. There are 20 original songs made for the primary campaign and 107 full length heavy metal songs that can be unlocked and played in-game through the Hot Rod's radio.\n\nVOICE ACTING: The main character Eddie is voiced by Jack Black and he does an amazing job of providing life to this character and making him truly enjoyable to watch and play as. The rest of the cast is all-star for Heavy Metal fans: Ozzy Osbourne
column31: plus other known names like Tim Curry and Jennifer Hale round out the amazing vocal talents this game has.\n\nSTORY: The story is a lot of fun to experience
column32: and while certainly not the best out there
column33:
it carries a lot of power and keeps you interested through-out. I only wished we got more of the story involving Succoria. By the time the game ends I felt ready to keep going!



All in all there's no reason not to play this game

reviewText:
This game starts with you saving the life of some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ band of rap metal (they die later).

After sacrificing yourself, you are teleported to an era that's very well designed. You can get lost in the design of the mountains and the structures around the land and you can enjoy a ride with good metal music in the background.

The enemies are very good designed and the voice acting is great. There's no enemy or ally that annoys you with their voice and they are all useful.

The battle system it's 3D Zelda based and you can unlock stuff the same way Link does it. Play the guitar to summon your car, to activate structures, to call a zeppelin on fire that insta-kill everyone around you when it crashes. It's good.

The only bad thing it's the lack of jumping. You are driving the car on the highway. You see the end of the road and in an attempt to not die you jump of the car because it's too late to stop it. You see yourself in a branch and there is a gap between you and the highway. You move and you fall to your death. You may ask How the ♥♥♥♥ did you manage to get in that situation?"
date: but I ask "How the ♥♥♥♥ I can get to the other side without dying?". You say jumping
recommended: but the game doesn't know what is that. You are dead."

reviewText:
There are a lot of things in this game you can either like, or hate. It's a decent game. Combining real-time strategy with action-adventure, Brütal Legend tells a story about the main character Eddie Riggs who helps Lars, Lita and Ophelia create an army to fight against the evil antagonist, in a heavy metal inspired world. The gameplay mechanics itself can be confusing, and controls aren't really comfortable. You can travel in an open world and do side missions, or continue the main story, which unfortunately only lasts about six hours. While doing the main story, you get to do these 'stage  battles', that's where the real-time strategy comes into play.

The game is supported by some absolutely awesome heavy metal music. Featuring over 100 great songs from popular artists like Motörhead, Megadeth, Judas Priest, Ozzy Osbourne, and many more, as well as a lot of excellent less known bands. Some voices have been done by musicians including Lemmy Kilmister, Rob Halford, Ozzy Osbourne and more. Not only the music but also the visuals are quite appealing, with lots of different themed areas and a unique graphical style. The story is fun, there's some good humour and the characters are very interesting. Truly a joy to play for metal fans, and still worth trying if you're not.

Gameplay however is lacking things. The controls aren't optimal and can be very confusing, even though the game tries its best to explain them. The hack-and-slash parts are pretty good, but the real-time strategy parts can be a bit overwhelming seeing as how much you have to handle at a time. The story is really short, clocking at about only six hours. There's a decent amount of side stuff to do, and dispite the flaws it's still fun to play.

If you like heavy metal music, dark themes, and like the idea of real-time strategy combined with action-adventure and hack-and-slash, then this game might be just for you. The game might not be great in terms of gameplay mechanics, but the concept is still awesome; and so is the music!

reviewText:
Do you want to melt the faces of emo posers with an electric guitar? What about with Ozzy, Lemmy, and Rob Halford backing you up? All with the most kick-♥♥♥ arranged and original soundtrack playing at the same time?
Brutal Legend is a game mortals are not yet worthy of. Hilarious and witty writing, tight and satisfying combat and even RTS/tower defense mechanics, all in a world that is a manifestation of every and all things traditional heavy metal and a satorization of its watered-down derivative genres.

At the Steam price, this game is a steal. A decently long campaign and fun multiplayer versus mode, you should buy this game just to ride around in your car to the classic 70's and 80's metal soundtrack alone.

reviewText:
I wish that Jack Black was in more games. Brütal Legend is an open world, action RPG from Double Fine Productions. Let’s get rocking.

The Good

I think the obvious answer to this is Jack Black.

If you’re a fan of Tenacious D, this game is pretty much Tenacious D: The Game.

The soundtrack is fantastic. Whether you’re cruising around in the Deuce or just wandering around seeing the sights, the blend of well known metal music and original composition is glorious.

There is a satisfyingly ample amount of items for you to unlock in the “Motor Forge”. Their are weapon upgrades for the Deuce, weapon upgrades for your character, and additional attacks to use. There are also purely cosmetic items to acquire, however, like paint jobs, new clothes, and giant stone heads.

There is a large array of enemies for you to hack to pieces as well as indigenous fauna for you to harass. All the designs are brilliant and very much metal influenced.

The story is great, the dialogue is funny, and the game never takes itself to seriously. This is a trait which we don’t see enough these days.

The map is surprisingly big and makes for a good amount of exploration.

The Bad

I’ve got nothing here, sorry.

The Meh

There’s no DLC, so, once the game is over, it’s over. This makes me a sad panda.

Verdict: Yea

If you’re a fan of jack Black, Tenacious D, or metal music, then BL is very much the game for you. You can pick it up in the Steam Store at your earliest convenience. It is money that you won’t regret spending. As always, thanks for reading.

reviewText: Fun and goofy, the game is worth playing. However, its controls are terrible, and the driving mechanics are rage-inducing. I can't even begin to think about the number of driving escort missions I failed multiple times in a row just because I was stuck on geometry and had to spend a minute or more trying to maneuver my way around so I could *maybe* get back on the path.\n\nThe game felt short, and after the final boss fight, I felt happy to see what the next area would be like, only to find myself watching the end credits. I felt like the game ended abruptly, either because they ran out of time, or because they're saving stuff for Brütal Legends 2. Either way, if it's on sale, give it a try.

reviewText: As I finished this game, I was left wondering why this game wasn't better received. Sure, the strategy mechanics are a little clunky in the stage battles and the combo mechanics aren't deep enough to sustain 100+ hours played. But the aesthetic is amazing, the story is great and it's amazing fun. A fun mix of open world brawler and strategy-lite, it doesn't overstay its welcome. The game is over well before the mechanics prove to be tiresome and while it's not the biggest game, the ride you do get is immensely entertaining.

reviewText: hello ladies and gentlemen,this is my review of Brütal Legend,the game was released on october of 2009 for the xbox 360 and the ps3,and in this year of 2013 double fine announced a pc port of the game via steam,but unfortunatelly the game didn't receive much attention because of its genres,which are Action-adventure and Real-time strategy,but let's talk about the game itself,the voice acting is very good,i personally find it flawless,the graphics are great,i simply loved the soundtrack,which is almost only heavy metal musics from lots of bands,107 tracks from 75 different bands,all the characters are memorable and lovable,also,the main character was voiced and modeled after Jack Black,the game's humor is good,i have to admit i had some good laughs with this game,the controls answer very well,the story is not something that great,its told slowly during the game,the game has a fair difficulty too,killing the enemies is very satisfying,but it can get a little repetitive,the world is really big,which you can explore while not doing a mission,there's also a multiplayer,which is quite fair,and can get really challenging,with a good number of maps,the AI is good,but if an AI is sent somewhere,for example,if it finds an enemy,its gonna go attack him,forgeting its original  command of going to a certain place.there are other two little problems,this one is probably because i'm not very good,but its about the racing side-missions,sometimes the game throws some curves that are quite hard to take,since the car can get really quick,it gets harder to do curves,you are gonna understand me better when you start using it,but that's just a little thing we all can ignore,but about the other one,it's fletus,the character you race against,when the player is pushed by fletus,it looks like it's a moving wall,not a car.in the end,the game is very good,though it has some flaws,but its not something that will ruin your experience,in the end,this game gets my rating of 9.2/10.00

reviewText: Being a Tim Schafer fanboy my review of this game is almost certainly biased, but I must say it was freaking excellent. As with other Double Fine games I found it difficult to adjust to the controls and felt like I had to fight them and the camera a fair bit, but it pays off entirely once you get the hang of it because the sheer manic fun of the game just makes it so worthwhile. An engaging storyline, clever comedy, star appeal, excellent graphic design, and even an awesome soundtrack. I've never been into rock or metal much, but this game has left me with an open mind about this sort of music and have been on something of a rock and metal musical quest ever since playing Brutal Legend. Kudos Tim Schafer, kudos. 9 out of 10, would head bang.

reviewText:
MOTION SICKNESS WARNING: You'll use a (kickin' rad) vehicle to get around Brutal Legend's sizeable sand box world, but due to its Heavy Metal theme, terrain is very uneven and makes steady smooth driving difficult. You'll be accelerating and decelerating at different rates, and this gave me a lot of nausea. If fast-moving games give you the same problem, then Brutal Legend may have the same effect.

That aside, Brutal Legend is more an experience rather than a game. Set in an intricately-designed landscape inspired by metal album covers, you step into the shoes of Jack Black/Eddie Riggs as you headbang your way through your foes in defense of all things Metal and righteous. As you progress through the main campaign, you will recruit hearty groups of warriors to your cause, adding to an army that will help you rock your way to victory.

However, the gameplay is lacking. There are three main mini-games" that Brutal Legend will keep bringing you back to: Third-Person Hack&Slash Action
recommended: and Driving. Main Campaign missions will typically focus on one of these  aspects
hoursPlayed: but frankly I never felt engaged enough with any of them.\n\nWith Hack&Slash Action
voteText: I just waded in and mashed the attack buttons
helpfulPercent: occasionally circling to avoid getting hit and letting my health regen. Fights are chaotic masses of blood and special effects
votesHelpful: making it hard for me to know what I did beyond haphazard slashing
votesTotal: or what can or did kill me and what I could've done to avoid that. With Real-Time Strategy
votesFunny: I spammed unit-building and just charged en masse to whatever needed killing the most. That's my own single-mindedness at fault more than anything
commentsCount: but the unit-selection wheel was hard to manage with the mouse which led me to my less-involved approach. Finally
column16: with Driving
column17: in addition to my nausea
column18: control of my vehicle didn't feel smooth and made it even less enjoyable for me.\n\nAlso
column19: there is a multiplayer option that focuses on the RTS aspect of Brutal Legend. I tried it once
column20: but the same objections I had for the gameplay earlier apply here as well. Also
column21: odds are good that you'll be facing a lot of players with much more RTS experience
column22: so try out AI opponents first.\n\nOverall
column23: I actually do still recommend this game; despite my grievances
column24: I did still enjoy the well-designed setting
column26: and Jack Black as Eddie Riggs is a very relatable protagonist. However
column27: I recommend this only as an interactive open-world movie that you only need to go through once
column28: and only to fans of heavy metal and/or Jack Black
column29: and also if said fans aren't prone to motion sickness.\n\nNote for OCD Collectors: Brutal Legend also has a lot of "collectibles" in the game
column30: and fortunately once you finish the main campaign...  you can get an item that acts as a collectible compass. It won't mark them out for you explicitly on the map
column31: but it will save you a few hours of squinting and searching."

reviewText: I thought this game looked interesting when it first came out on consoles but, I didn't end up buying it. Then I saw it on sale on steam and I figured I would give it a try. I am not a huge metal fan. Before I played this game I was into some metal but, I never really heard of a lot of these classic metal bands. This game changed all of that, as soon as I began playing I got into the metal theme and music. The game is about a roadie named  Eddie Riggs (Jack Black) who is transported to a metal themed world after a terrible accident at a concert. This game features a Stellar sound track and cast, as well as a unique concept. The game play is a mix between some basic hack n slash, drive/shoot mechanics and some RTS elements. I am one of the people that didn't enjoy the RTS elements of the game, wich require you to play guitar solos to build fan booths on predetermined points used to spawn allies. You also get demon wings during these sections that allow you to move across the battlefield and command your army. The first time was fun but, after that it became tedious and somewhat frustrating. Though I do appreciate the unique use of RTS elements. However, this didn't stop me from enjoying the rest of the game because I liked the other elements of the game enough to force myself to get through the RTS sections. All in all I enjoyed the game and I couldn't be happier with my purchase if only to introduce me to some kick a$$ metal that I had missed out on for the first 21 years of my life. If you appreciate unique ideas, good music, good humor, and a strong cast, then I would recommend this game. If you have doubts then wait until it's on sell, at that point you can't go wrong.  \m/ Rock on!

reviewText:
(Disclaimer: This is a completely un-ironic and non-satirical review. Most of my other reviews are silly and are supposed to be funny, but this is a 100% true account of this video game.)

I know that at the time of me writing this review, it says that I have barely any hours put into this game. This is true for the PC, as I just bought it on sale. However, already having 150+ hours on console, I feel that I can effectively write a review of this game. Brutal Legend has been, since I bought it in early 2010, one of my favorite video games of all time. I do not say this lightly; this game has touched me personally and changed me. This game introduced me largely to what i am today.
First, a little backstory. I was blessed with a very musical family. Me, my brother, and my father all play instruments, and I have been around guitars and hard rock ranging from ACDC to Metallica from a young age. My parents are both fans of metal, and so from a young age, I listened to music like Iron Maiden, Motley Crue, and Dragonforce, just to name a few. One of the earliest band shirts I ever remember wearing was an Iron Maiden shirt in first grade.
Video game have also been a medium for my family for years; we've had consoles ranging from the Saturn to the Dreamcast to the N64 to the PS1 to the original Xbox, and we still have a plethora of consoles to this day. I have always been a fan of video games, and luckily my parents don't mind what kind I play; in fact, some of my fondest memories were of playing Halo 2 system link with my parents in their room and me and my older brother in the living room (my father drilled a hole in our wall to make this possible).
Anyways, shortly after the game came out (about February 2010) we went to Best Buy. I had some money left over from my birthday in January (I believe I just turned 11, and was in fifth grade), and I wanted to get a video game. The choice came down to Red Faction: Guerrilla or Brutal Legend. After carefully reading the backs, I decided I had to choose: destruction, or heavy metal? I ended up buying Brutal Legend; however, I did buy Red Faction a few months later.
So I went home, and it being a weekend, I played the game for hours. I beat the game in a few days, but continued to play it for much longer. I believe that the last time I've played, I had every tab, and I know I had every upgrade. I beat the game on Brutal at one point. I believed this game was pure perfection. When I was younger, as I've said, I only really listened to some baby metal; this game showed me the wonders of different subgenres. I've come a long way over the years, all thanks to this game. I started out with bands like Dethklok, and now I listen to all different types of metal, with my favorite being Atmospheric Black Metal along the lines of Summoning and Drudkh. This game was the reason for all of this.
Another amazing aspect of the game was simply the detail in the characters and the world. I found the game mesmerizing as a child, and believed it was hilarious; not just in the dialogue, but the depiction of the stereotypes. I remember laughing with my father as he expressed amazement at the fact that Lemmy, Ozzy, and Halford were in the game. I remember thinking it was the funniest thing as I reamed goth people in a car while blaring speed metal. I remember the depictions of Hair Metal kids as sellouts, and loving it. Understanding the references may not be hard, but for a fifth grader, it was liberating, finally being able to understand comedy.
As for the gameplay itself, the game isn't that amazing. Basic combat and the clunky RTS elements make it a bit awkward, but the game more than makes up for it in sentimental value and world design. I eagerly, and relatively naively await the day that Double Fine announces Brutal Legend 2, despite the fact that it probably won't even happen. When it does, it will be among one of the games that I have preordered, a list that as of now only consists of Bioshock 2 (a severe disappointment in my eyes) and Dark Souls 2.
In conclusion, Brutal Legend is an amazing game that has a special place in my heart. This review may not be too helpful, as I recognize the fact that it's all sweaty fanboy-ism, but I felt that I had to let other people in on a personal experience I've had with the game. If you are a fan of heavy metal, play this game. If you aren't a fan of heavy metal, still play this game, because the amount of detail and the humor are still enjoyable. Plus, maybe it could broaden your musical tastes and FORCE you to like metal! In any case, I cannot recommend this game enough. I have had more enjoyment with this game and hold it in higher esteem than any other, except perhaps Dark Souls. This game changed me as a human being, for better or for worse, and while it may not touch you in the same way that it touched a cringy antisocial preteen (THAT SENTENCE SHOULD NEVER COME OUT OF ANYONE'S MOUTH), you may still find some enjoyment in it. Hell, if you buy it on sale, you pretty much just spent three bucks on Drive Around and Kill ♥♥♥♥ While Metal Plays Simulator". If you can't find enjoyment in that

reviewText:
Brütal legend is a third person action adventure that incorporates gameplay elements from various different genres.

The roadie Eddie Riggs is transported to a world in which all the over the top heavy metal imagery one knows from album covers is actually real. He quickly learns that the humans who live here are under threat by a demon emperor named Doviculus who installed a puppet government led by a man  called General Lionwhyte. While Eddie does not want to be a hero and actually hates to stay in the spotlight he gets caught up in the revolution against the demons and decides to do what he can to liberate mankind. Soon Eddie finds out that his presence in this world may not be a mere coincidence and that there's something connecting him to it.

Brütal Legend clearly isn't the conventional type of game. It encompasses elements of hack&slash, open world driving, real time strategy and a bit of guitar hero. It plays like a mix of hack and slash, real time strategy, sandbox and a little bit of guitar hero. Eddie fights using his axe as well as his guitar. While the axe is obviously a melee weapon the guitar can be used to execute ranged attacks as well as solos. While many solos are obtained naturally while progressing to through the game some have to be found. Every solo has a unique effect that can be triggered by playing the solo through hitting the right buttons at the right time. For example there is a solo which summons allied beasts as well as another one that causes mass destruction via the crash of a giant burning zeppelin. Eddie can also run over enemies using his car. Later the car can be upgraded with a variety of weapons. The car has one slot for a high range weapon that shoots from the front as well as a for short range weapon that shoots from the sides of the car.

After the introduction Eddie is free to explore the world and either follow the main quest, various side quests or search for collectibles. Collectibles mostly come as songs for your car stereo but can also be guitar solos. Upgrades and sidegrades can be purchased at the Guardian of Metal who resides in the underground Motor Forge. Entrances to the Motor Forge can be found all over the land.

At some point in the game Brütal Legend introduces real-time strategy elements that will from that point on play an important role. When a battle is coming up both factions construct a stage where units can be recruited. Recruiting units costs fans and while you gain fans over time capturing checkpoints greatly speeds up the process. During a strategy battle you still control Eddie in a third person perspective. While recruiting units, issuing orders and setting up rally points you can yourself take part in the battle by attacking or using solos. You can also perform combo attacks which are different depending on the unit you combo with. For example comboing with Headbangers creates a mosh pit. If you die you respawn at your stage. The stage can be upgraded two times during the battle to unlock higher tier units. You win as soon as the enemies' stage is destroyed. Brütal Legend's multiplayer part consists of those real time strategy battles. There are three playable factions in multiplayer: Ironheade - the band-army of Eddie and his allies, the goth-themed Drowning Doom and Tainted Coil - the army of Doviculus the demon emperor. The fourth faction present in the campaign, the glam-metal themed army of General Lionwhyte, is not playable since it consists of recolors of Ironheade's units.

Brütal Legend features some great cameos like Jack Black as Eddie Riggs, Ozzy Osbourne as the Guardian of Metal, Lemmy Kilmister as the Kill Master, Rob Halford as the Baron as well as General Lionwhyte and Kyle Gass as Kage the Kannonier. Also, Jennifer Hale, Tim Curry and Lita Ford do non-cameo voice acting as Ophelia, Doviculus and Rima.

Due to the amount of gameplay elements none of them have been implemented as in a game that solely focuses on those. Brütal Legend has hack&slash gameplay but it's not a Devil May Cry or Chivalry: Medieval Warfare. If features open world driving but it's not a Saint's Row or GTA. It has real-time strategy but it's surely not a Starcraft or Command & Conquer. Also the solos are certainly not something out of Guitar Hero. What's more, the sidequests are often carbon copies of one another and thus can be very bland and repetitive. Also due to problems during development the game is not as long as it was originally meant to be. One whole faction which was originally planned is not present in the actual game. Also, the strategy elements are introduced rather late in the game considering the central role they play from that point on.

Brütal Legend is a mix of genres that kind of created its own genre. For some players that might indeed come off as weird and or too experimental. Also as stated above the game lacks polish in various places. However there are many things Brütal Legend gets right with its lovable characters, humorous tone, and glorious world, epic music and art design. Thus I still recommend it. If you are not afraid of trying something new and original and if you are a music fan you should give Brütal Legend a try.
