reviewText:
This game is just another title from Double Fine. And we all know that that means...

There are three qualities to this game that make it worthy of the hype it has gotten. For Simplicity's sake, I'll label them.

It's true to the source material.
This is suprising since the source material is just Metal. Metal songs, and metal cover art, and that's it. Now drive around the land that the game takes place in, and tell me that you can't take a screenshot of ANY LANDMARK, slap a random cover title on it, and tell someone that it's a real CD cover. This is quite spectacular, but it's nothing for Double Fine. They seem to specialize in surreal locations that others couldn't imagine existing. They made Psychonauts, after all. They also use metal instruments for all background songs. ALL OF THEM. (Sadly, you won't hear it that often because you're too busy listening to the 107+ metal songs on the radio in your car) If you are a hardcore Metal fan, you won't be disappointed.

Characters applenty.
As a Double Fine game, it makes sense that every character has lines for any situation that they can get into in game. Your allies sees Eddie play a song? Compliments come in. They see Eddie take off? They can say that your wings look cool, or tell you not to leave them, depending on the circumstances. Also, the commentary is hilarious. The guy that takes the case though, is Eddie Riggs, the main character, who is voiced by Jack Black (the voice behind Po in Kung Fu Panda, among others). He takes the cake by staying true to the character of a Metal Roadie thrusted into the world of Brutal Legends, all the while showing off his incredible comedy skills.

Real Time Strategy goes fast paced.
Now, when have you heard strategy and intense being used together. At all? It's incredibly rare, and hard to pull off, but Brutal Legends did it. They made a Strategy game that's more than amassing troops and sending them at the enemy base before they reach yours (Although that still works). With nuke solos, powerful double teams, and various other nasty tricks to pull, the RTS element of the game, the Multiplayer Stage Battles, is incredible, capable of turning the tables with the right move, and mixing hack and slash into there so you can join the fun of killing your enemy's troops over and over again! And with three different factions, each with their own playstyle and strategies to pull off, you can enjoy it again and again.

If you kile RTS games, Metal, or the works of Double Fine, this is a game that won't disapoint. If you have an aversion to any of these, then run now, and never come back.

reviewText:
(Disclaimer: This is a completely un-ironic and non-satirical review. Most of my other reviews are silly and are supposed to be funny, but this is a 100% true account of this video game.)

I know that at the time of me writing this review, it says that I have barely any hours put into this game. This is true for the PC, as I just bought it on sale. However, already having 150+ hours on console, I feel that I can effectively write a review of this game. Brutal Legend has been, since I bought it in early 2010, one of my favorite video games of all time. I do not say this lightly; this game has touched me personally and changed me. This game introduced me largely to what i am today.
First, a little backstory. I was blessed with a very musical family. Me, my brother, and my father all play instruments, and I have been around guitars and hard rock ranging from ACDC to Metallica from a young age. My parents are both fans of metal, and so from a young age, I listened to music like Iron Maiden, Motley Crue, and Dragonforce, just to name a few. One of the earliest band shirts I ever remember wearing was an Iron Maiden shirt in first grade.
Video game have also been a medium for my family for years; we've had consoles ranging from the Saturn to the Dreamcast to the N64 to the PS1 to the original Xbox, and we still have a plethora of consoles to this day. I have always been a fan of video games, and luckily my parents don't mind what kind I play; in fact, some of my fondest memories were of playing Halo 2 system link with my parents in their room and me and my older brother in the living room (my father drilled a hole in our wall to make this possible).
Anyways, shortly after the game came out (about February 2010) we went to Best Buy. I had some money left over from my birthday in January (I believe I just turned 11, and was in fifth grade), and I wanted to get a video game. The choice came down to Red Faction: Guerrilla or Brutal Legend. After carefully reading the backs, I decided I had to choose: destruction, or heavy metal? I ended up buying Brutal Legend; however, I did buy Red Faction a few months later.
So I went home, and it being a weekend, I played the game for hours. I beat the game in a few days, but continued to play it for much longer. I believe that the last time I've played, I had every tab, and I know I had every upgrade. I beat the game on Brutal at one point. I believed this game was pure perfection. When I was younger, as I've said, I only really listened to some baby metal; this game showed me the wonders of different subgenres. I've come a long way over the years, all thanks to this game. I started out with bands like Dethklok, and now I listen to all different types of metal, with my favorite being Atmospheric Black Metal along the lines of Summoning and Drudkh. This game was the reason for all of this.
Another amazing aspect of the game was simply the detail in the characters and the world. I found the game mesmerizing as a child, and believed it was hilarious; not just in the dialogue, but the depiction of the stereotypes. I remember laughing with my father as he expressed amazement at the fact that Lemmy, Ozzy, and Halford were in the game. I remember thinking it was the funniest thing as I reamed goth people in a car while blaring speed metal. I remember the depictions of Hair Metal kids as sellouts, and loving it. Understanding the references may not be hard, but for a fifth grader, it was liberating, finally being able to understand comedy.
As for the gameplay itself, the game isn't that amazing. Basic combat and the clunky RTS elements make it a bit awkward, but the game more than makes up for it in sentimental value and world design. I eagerly, and relatively naively await the day that Double Fine announces Brutal Legend 2, despite the fact that it probably won't even happen. When it does, it will be among one of the games that I have preordered, a list that as of now only consists of Bioshock 2 (a severe disappointment in my eyes) and Dark Souls 2.
In conclusion, Brutal Legend is an amazing game that has a special place in my heart. This review may not be too helpful, as I recognize the fact that it's all sweaty fanboy-ism, but I felt that I had to let other people in on a personal experience I've had with the game. If you are a fan of heavy metal, play this game. If you aren't a fan of heavy metal, still play this game, because the amount of detail and the humor are still enjoyable. Plus, maybe it could broaden your musical tastes and FORCE you to like metal! In any case, I cannot recommend this game enough. I have had more enjoyment with this game and hold it in higher esteem than any other, except perhaps Dark Souls. This game changed me as a human being, for better or for worse, and while it may not touch you in the same way that it touched a cringy antisocial preteen (THAT SENTENCE SHOULD NEVER COME OUT OF ANYONE'S MOUTH), you may still find some enjoyment in it. Hell, if you buy it on sale, you pretty much just spent three bucks on Drive Around and Kill ♥♥♥♥ While Metal Plays Simulator". If you can't find enjoyment in that

reviewText:
This was the game that got me into heavy metal.

Pros (Single Player):

- Unique story that you just can't make up, and is almost impossible to describe properly
- An open, epic world inspired by multiple classical metal albums
- You can melt faces with epic solos
- An epic Heavy Metal soundtrack featuring over 100 songs from renowned artists such as Cradle of Filth, Manowar, Dimmu Borgir, Slayer, Tenacious D, KISS, Dethklok, and Judas Priest
- Cameos by all sorts of rock/metal artists such as Jack Black, Rob Halford, Lita Ford, and Ozzy Osbourne


Cons (Single Player):

- You can't jump
- Unable to play any of the other factions, even if I DID want to be the Hair Metal Militia
- Unable to be modded, it seems
- So many different game types melded into one game makes it seem a bit schizophrenic, and going through an identity crisis. Is it a tower defense game? Is it Hack and Slash? Is it a Racing game? Is it Escort Missions? Is it Guitar Hero? Yes. And while it is done fairly well, it can be problematic for some
- My biggest problem is that you can only fly during stage battles. Yeah. You can fly, but only in Stage battles. Bull.


Brutal Legend also has a Multiplayer mode, but due to crappy internet, and the fact I run a potato, it is almost impossible for me to give a fair analysis of this. Don't come here for that sort of thing. I won't review it.

recommended: just enjoying jamming your guitars to shock (literally) your enemies and then fend them off with your trusty Axe. If you are an open-minded metalhead or just someone looking for a bit of fun while slashing enemies

reviewText:
Brütal legend is a third person action adventure that incorporates gameplay elements from various different genres.

The roadie Eddie Riggs is transported to a world in which all the over the top heavy metal imagery one knows from album covers is actually real. He quickly learns that the humans who live here are under threat by a demon emperor named Doviculus who installed a puppet government led by a man  called General Lionwhyte. While Eddie does not want to be a hero and actually hates to stay in the spotlight he gets caught up in the revolution against the demons and decides to do what he can to liberate mankind. Soon Eddie finds out that his presence in this world may not be a mere coincidence and that there's something connecting him to it.

Brütal Legend clearly isn't the conventional type of game. It encompasses elements of hack&slash, open world driving, real time strategy and a bit of guitar hero. It plays like a mix of hack and slash, real time strategy, sandbox and a little bit of guitar hero. Eddie fights using his axe as well as his guitar. While the axe is obviously a melee weapon the guitar can be used to execute ranged attacks as well as solos. While many solos are obtained naturally while progressing to through the game some have to be found. Every solo has a unique effect that can be triggered by playing the solo through hitting the right buttons at the right time. For example there is a solo which summons allied beasts as well as another one that causes mass destruction via the crash of a giant burning zeppelin. Eddie can also run over enemies using his car. Later the car can be upgraded with a variety of weapons. The car has one slot for a high range weapon that shoots from the front as well as a for short range weapon that shoots from the sides of the car.

After the introduction Eddie is free to explore the world and either follow the main quest, various side quests or search for collectibles. Collectibles mostly come as songs for your car stereo but can also be guitar solos. Upgrades and sidegrades can be purchased at the Guardian of Metal who resides in the underground Motor Forge. Entrances to the Motor Forge can be found all over the land.

At some point in the game Brütal Legend introduces real-time strategy elements that will from that point on play an important role. When a battle is coming up both factions construct a stage where units can be recruited. Recruiting units costs fans and while you gain fans over time capturing checkpoints greatly speeds up the process. During a strategy battle you still control Eddie in a third person perspective. While recruiting units, issuing orders and setting up rally points you can yourself take part in the battle by attacking or using solos. You can also perform combo attacks which are different depending on the unit you combo with. For example comboing with Headbangers creates a mosh pit. If you die you respawn at your stage. The stage can be upgraded two times during the battle to unlock higher tier units. You win as soon as the enemies' stage is destroyed. Brütal Legend's multiplayer part consists of those real time strategy battles. There are three playable factions in multiplayer: Ironheade - the band-army of Eddie and his allies, the goth-themed Drowning Doom and Tainted Coil - the army of Doviculus the demon emperor. The fourth faction present in the campaign, the glam-metal themed army of General Lionwhyte, is not playable since it consists of recolors of Ironheade's units.

Brütal Legend features some great cameos like Jack Black as Eddie Riggs, Ozzy Osbourne as the Guardian of Metal, Lemmy Kilmister as the Kill Master, Rob Halford as the Baron as well as General Lionwhyte and Kyle Gass as Kage the Kannonier. Also, Jennifer Hale, Tim Curry and Lita Ford do non-cameo voice acting as Ophelia, Doviculus and Rima.

Due to the amount of gameplay elements none of them have been implemented as in a game that solely focuses on those. Brütal Legend has hack&slash gameplay but it's not a Devil May Cry or Chivalry: Medieval Warfare. If features open world driving but it's not a Saint's Row or GTA. It has real-time strategy but it's surely not a Starcraft or Command & Conquer. Also the solos are certainly not something out of Guitar Hero. What's more, the sidequests are often carbon copies of one another and thus can be very bland and repetitive. Also due to problems during development the game is not as long as it was originally meant to be. One whole faction which was originally planned is not present in the actual game. Also, the strategy elements are introduced rather late in the game considering the central role they play from that point on.

Brütal Legend is a mix of genres that kind of created its own genre. For some players that might indeed come off as weird and or too experimental. Also as stated above the game lacks polish in various places. However there are many things Brütal Legend gets right with its lovable characters, humorous tone, and glorious world, epic music and art design. Thus I still recommend it. If you are not afraid of trying something new and original and if you are a music fan you should give Brütal Legend a try.

reviewText:
A game brimming with heart and style, lacking not in quality but in an identity and proper marketing.

Graphics and art style hold up today with every landscape, monster and toon serving as a gorgeous tribute to its subject matter.  Animation does get buggy at times, but seldom enough to rip you from the experience.

The music and soundtrack for this game is exceptional for enthusiasts.  A solid variety of tunes from various genres of metal are sure to appease all but the most discerning of music palettes.  Voice acting is top notch for the most part, at least when it comes to the big name VAs.

Story holds your attention.  It's not going to reverberate in your mind when you're done playing the game, but isn't so awful that it gets in the way of your enjoyment.  The humor and dialogue holds up alright, but again, won't win any awards.  Your love of the writing will likely be based on your love of Jack Black or the various musicians/actors who cameoed in this game.

Where the game still falls short to this day is its attempt to make a console friendly RTS.  Controls are streamlined enough to only allow for the broadest of unit management.  Keyboard and mouse controls do help, but little effort was made to properly port this title to PC (game still uses a controller friendly radial menu for Solos and army building for instance).  This can sadly make some of the RTS segments feel like a grind compared to the action portion of the title, especially if you're struggling to get through a segment to advance the game.

The action controls also sadly suffer in the PC port.  Having to hold a lock button down in order to dodge feels wrong, and not allowing the player to remap it as a toggle switch discourages its use entirely.  Futzing with the radial menu for solos will require adapation to feel natural.  Thankfully, mouse control for camera does alleviate some of the control issues with the previous game.  The driving also feels better in the PC port compared to the console.

Online community has largely left this game, but the campaign and single player experience is certainly worth the buy in.  The map is impressive in size and hides all sorts of secret goodies that will have you hunting around for a good deal of hours if you're the completionist type.  Driving is a thrill and just cruising around the map while a favorite song plays on the radio can hold your interest.  Side missions give you lots to do, but it can get very samey very quickly (So many Ironheade sneak attack missions are the exact same setup).  The game gives you plenty of fire tributes (in game currency used to purchase upgrades), so you can thankfully cherry pick those mini games that appeal to you, or simply harvest them from the collectibles.

Sadly, because the online community has left, you're opportunities to play as the other factions within the game are limited principally to AI skirmishes.

Bugs do creep up from time to time.  Minor visual bugs can take you out of a cutscene, but haven't yet cropped up during gameplay.  Game has crashed to desktop on me once, but no progress was lost due to rigorous auto-save system and being fortunate enough to not be on a mission.  Moving in and out of the map and menus can also be an inconsistent experience (sometimes pausing the game, sometimes not).

Despite my issues with the game overall, it's still very playable.  It is both a tribute to metal while itself being a work of visual and auditory art.  If metal music or culture are of any interest to you or if you ever wanted to try a game that's a chunky blend of God of War, Grand Theft Auto and Dawn of War, this game is worth a purchase.  Those seeking a competitive RTS experience should look elsewhere.

reviewText:
That's right, the game hasn't even been released yet and I'm already writing a review for it. What's up with that ? For starters, Brutal Legend is a game that has to be experienced. It's an open world action adventure with a few RTS elements added to it (more on that in a bit).

Think of any open world game, add a heavy metal flavour to this world, throw some heavy metal music in there as well and voila, you pretty much have Brutal Legend.

It's charming, looks great and above all, it's fun. Except for one thing... Which brings me back to the RTS part. There are a few missions where you have to build an army and engage your enemies in combat, RTS style. And even though it works - it's perfectly playable - it just... It just isn't any fun. It's more of a chore when I think about it. This part is the only negative thing I can think of.
But, don't let that keep you from buying it. Brutal Legend, like most of the Double Fine games, is one brilliant game. Do yourself a favor and just buy it already.

[Rating: 84/100]

reviewText:
Brutal Legend

Brütal Legend is an action-adventure that marries visceral action combat with open-world freedom. Set in a universe somewhere between Lord of the Rings and Spinal Tap, it’s a fresh take on the action/driving genre, which in this case is full of imitation cover bands, demons intent on enslaving humanity and Heavy metal tunes. If you don't already own this game, then you are missing out BIG TIME.Brutal Legend was released on the 26th Feburary 2013 and i am loving this game so far, In this game it has everything a human wants  in a ,Film Music, Entertainment , Comedy, Action and lots more. This game is superb, It is controller supported so i recommend you play with a controller and the driving, the killing is all fantastic.

Pros:
- Humorous.
- Good Driving.
- Good actions.
- Easy to play.
- Liking the single-player.

Cons :
- The combat is weak.
- Freedom of the explorable open world largely wasted.
- The action is often floaty.

Despite its weaknesses, Brütal Legend pulls it off. It’s the ultimate tribute act, with metal in its soul and a heart as warm as a stage light. It may not have much in the way of polish, especially years after release, but it does have personality – not enough to hide its flaws, but plenty to temporarily bury them under a landslide of rock. I would definitely recommend Brutal Legend and i will give this game a 9/10 because the Weak Combat just didn't impress me that much but this game is FANTASTIC and definitely worth buying.

reviewText: I love so much about this game I have to say buy it.  I grew up listening to metal in the 80's and worked as a roadie in the 90's, so it's a moral imperative that I recommend this game.  I love the humor, the music, and the brutal mayhem of the game, but that said, who the F**** programmed the car driving?  For such a  major part of the game, the driving mechanic nearly sinks it. reviewText:
I love this game.  A huge part of this is the just awesome soundtrack along with an entertaining storyline.  Ozzie, Motley Crue, Megadeth, Judas Priest, Black Sabbath, KISS, Anthrax, Motorhead, Tenacious D, and more.  On top of a linear storyline, there are a lot of optional side missions which are purely for tokens for upgrades to your car, weapons, car weapons.

I am not done with the game yet but I have to say I love Jack Black and this game is a lot about him too.   His humor and characters speaks literally as you play the part of Eddie.

The game also has suprisingly tactical warcraft elements.  Besides the first person, hack and slash, car driving shoot and run over things you have storyline missions where you take tacticaly points, generate resources, train units, upgrade and move against the enemy.  While that occurs you also can drive, fly (I know, weird) or run around the battle field to help out in person or more manually control groups of units.

A lot of elements from this game have been borrowed from other games, but it has been brought together in an entertaining story, action combo filled hack and slash.  All along with great music.  Highly recommended.

A couple other notes, you can play the game on gently, normal, or brutal (I have only played on brutal) and with or without gore and profanity.

reviewText:
Very underrated game imho.
The story is very fun and entertaining in my opinion, even if you are not a Heavy Metal Fan (but it helps being one). I think the writers did a good job of combining a great string of original ideas with classic heavy metal lore. Only downside is that the main story is a bit short for my taste (i must confess, i could not get enough of it), linear and the climax was a bit disappointing. They clearly tried too hard to set the story up for a sequel, which probably will never be developed.

The gameplay itself is fun, although a slightly repetitive. You basically have 3 kinds of missions: Hack'n'Slay-style main missions, exciting driving missions and the battlefield missions which were a great new idea, but didn't fulfill their potential despite being fun aswell. The optional side missions lack variety and proper incentive (besides some points to buy power-ups and clothes / car kits your really get nothing from them)... they could have done a better job including side missions into the story, like getting 4-5 minor storylines into the game. As I said, it's very linear. Some people may consider it a weak spot, but i think it's cool that you can choose to simply beat the bejeezus out of everyone with the standard moves or get and use all special moves to maximize your efficiency. I personally found the specials generally useless and there was no tactical aspect to the game... it's more of an arcade-style gameplay. Controls are ok on PC, but you clearly notice this game was made primarily for consoles and dumbed down" for a broader audience. Too bad they failed at promoting it accordingly.

Graphics are appropriate for their time and serve their purpose. Don't expect any fireworks... this game is about fun and originality
date: not cutting edge technology. The Soundtrack is absolutely fantastic and really helps you immerse into the game world. Voice acting is also tremendous with tons of cool guest appearances (i.e. Kyle Gass of Tenacious D and Lemmy from Motörhead). Level design is absolutely off the hook although you can beat the game by essentially giving your enemies the Diablo 2-barbarian-treatment  all the time (charge head-on - kill everything in sight with brute force - move on).\n\nBottom line: This game is a one-trick-pony
recommended: but that one trick is really really awesome. It's not worth a release-date pricetag
hoursPlayed: but a solid and fun game. If you want about 20-30 hours of straightforward fun and a short
voteText: yet entertaining story to fill some "time off" from the games you usually play
helpfulPercent: you'll have a good time with BL. If you are someone that prefers showing off his/her skills
votesHelpful: looting/practicing for multiplayer games or spend hours getting every achievement
votesTotal: i recommend sticking to some MMORPG or FPS."

reviewText: (Four horns for the metal; two for the game itself)\n\nThis is fantastic game for metal heads, primarily, for all the in-jokes and chuckle-worthy self awareness. Black's dialogue and delivery is priceless as is the fantastic writing by Mr. Schafer himself. The PC version is more than 'just a port', looking and moving far superior to the console editions. The controls are fantastic, specifically with a gamepad. The only issue I have with the game, really, is that combat can be far too simplistic and frantic to be as fun as one might imagine it would be. Also, once the game introduces RTS elements in the form of squads and minions, it goes from 'true metal' to 'nu-metal' in terms enjoyment. That being said, there is a great story here with an enjoyable cast of characters and satirical achetypes. The game overall is great fun, and exploration and a joy. It's a shame that it couldn't decide if it was an adventure game, beat 'em up or a strategy game.

reviewText: *Single Player only - I haven't tried multiplayer*\nOh Double Fine, how I love you. This game is based around heavy metal, with a wonderful landscape inspired by it and a soundtrack with 20 original compositions and around 80 licensed tracks, and voice actors including Ozzy Osbourne and Jack Black. This game starts off as more of a Hack and Slash, with bits of rhythm and exciting driving sections. Later, a lot more of the game becomes RTS, which on easier difficulties you can win with just brute force over strategy, helpful for those who aren't great at the genre. The teams are also based on metal genres, as well as a wide, interesting variety of different classes for each one, as well as the ability to fight in the fight yourself at anytime. Only real problem with this game is its length, which can be fixed by making a sequel. PLEASE TIM, PLEEEEASE!

reviewText:
If you're buying this game looking for a serious, intensely challenging and/or revolutionary game, keep the wallet shut. This game's big, dumb and ridiculous, and that's exactly where the joy in it lies.

It's easily accessible to just about anyone, controls are simplistic for the most part, but the RTS elements are a little challenging at first. The story in itself is pretty much exactly what you'd expect from a videogame combining Jack Black and Metal, and it's a great laugh.

The locations, however, are what make the game really stand out. All the major locations are based on real-life album covers by famous bands, and even just driving around, along cliffs made of amplifiers, dodging giant swords sticking out the ground, makes you genuinely feel like you're inside an album.

Furthermore, guest appearances by Ozzy and Lemmy! What can go wrong?

A game specifically for fans of good old-fashioned heavy metal, with glorious locations, ridiculous action and a soundtrack that's simply perfect, definitely worth the cash. Go buy it!

reviewText:
Impressive how someone can turn a simple theme such as an musical style (in this case Heavy Metal) into an epic experience so full of references.

Everything in the game dwells on the characteristics that compose Heavy Metal in such an spectacular way that even someone like me, who doesnt have the knowledge on the style is mesmerised by all its elements.

The story seems a little lackluster in the beginning but it picks up and the extras give it a shine showing a little unexpected lore.

The Mechanics develop little by little and are fun since the get-go but they get repetitive near the end.

The only part on it that didnt captivate me was on the strategy part since its quite simple and that kind of genre requires some complexity to really last.

The game has an awesome theme development, with an inspiring soundtrack for your epic journey & funny dialogues in the style that only Double Fine brings.

reviewText: Ok, honestly I was hoping for an hour or two of low-brow entertainment for my money.  To say my expectations were low isn't an understatement.  However, I found an incredibly fun action game, with a well told story.  The voice acting was exceptional all the way around, and the music is a solid sample from all over the genre.  The game took all of the outrageous sillyness in the basic concept is stride and embraced it in a way that had me smiling at the jokes rather than groaning.\n\nI lost a weekend to this game and enjoyed every minute of it.  It's a bit easy compared to other action titles, but the story is good enough that it doesn't matter.  This game is one of those that I wouldn't have been upset to pay full price for, so the current price is completely worth it.  If you have even the slightest interest, don't pass this up!

reviewText:
This is an awesome tongue in cheek tribute to all that is Heavy Metal. In typical Double-Fine tradition the world is presented in an inventive manner, with a cast of interesting characters, voiced by an excellent line up.


Pros
- Awesome Metal soundtrack (and official score for that matter)
- Good sense of humour
- Fantastic selection of voice actors and Heavy Metal cameos
- World is fun to explore
- Reasonably good pacing (teaching and unlocking most abilities at a good rate)


Cons
- RTS sections may put you off if you are expecting purely hack-and-slash.
- It's not really obvious how much damage you are inflicting or is being done to your units (there are some visual hints, but in the heat of the RTS sections I wasn't really picking up on these)
- (RTS) Tanking isn't really an option, so most unit upgrading/advancing feels pointless (even on hardest difficulty)

I've had a blast playing this. I'd recommend this for Heavy Metal fans in particular for the soundtrack and whimsical take on the genre(s).  :)

reviewText: I picked this up on sale for about 80% off assuming it would be good for a laugh or two then something to move on from. Instead I was hit with engaging characters, an amazing compilation of various metal sound tracks, fun missions and a memorable story. Sure, Jack Black voicing the main character was fun to listen to, but everything in the game was just so wonderfully done aswell from beautiful bright and dark landscapes to even the little details of having rose bushes made out of rocker fists. I feel this game didn't get the credit it deserves around gamers. The only thing that I felt hindered my fun was the hunting questlines which were dry and only a little memorable because of Brian Posehn rocking a very cool NPC questgiver. I played about 16 hours in total for about 3 dollars and enjoyed almost every minute of it. Grab it if it goes on sale :)

reviewText: While it has its flaws Brutal Legend is one of the most entertaining games I have played. The first of the games two major draws is the amazing world Tim Schafer and co. created. You can screenshot the game at almost any moment and there will be something amazing on screen. The art design for the game is breathtaking esspecially for fans of heavy metal like myself. It's a world made from the stuff of album covers and it's well worth visiting.\n\nThe other major draw is the soundtrack. I remember when the game was being promoted they had a video of Tim Schafer solving a rubix cube before they could list all the names of the bands represented. To make things even sweet some of the members of those bands are in the voice cast for this game. Ozzy is particular has a wonderful role here. The songs are used throughout the game both while exploring the overworld through your car radio and to set the mood for missions in the game. I cant think of a single instance where a song felt out of place. In fact sometimes the music felt so right I couldnt help but grin from ear to ear.

reviewText:
I did not just buy this for the TF2 promo's, I also bought it because it is the most metal game ever made and I will tell you why.
For one, this game has the best soundtrack ever compiled for one game. You may enjoy that one Kpop song right before your sprite fighting game, but for real, unbridled power and sheer metal, this is the place to start. From Black Sabbath to DragonForce everything is on here (Except metallica and Iron Maiden, they wanted more money.)
The Single player mode like Zelda, only with Hotrods instead of horses, Ozzy Osbourne instead of great fairies and the world is based on Metal Album covers. The Multiplayer is perhaps the only RTS game designed for a controller that actually works, and it works like a bat outta hell.
If that wasn't enough, the voice cast is stellar and it is blast from begin to end. Granted that they finally allow you to play the whole game when the BETA is over.

reviewText:
If you're buying this game looking for a serious, intensely challenging and/or revolutionary game, keep the wallet shut. This game's big, dumb and ridiculous, and that's exactly where the joy in it lies.

It's easily accessible to just about anyone, controls are simplistic for the most part, but the RTS elements are a little challenging at first. The story in itself is pretty much exactly what you'd expect from a videogame combining Jack Black and Metal, and it's a great laugh.

The locations, however, are what make the game really stand out. All the major locations are based on real-life album covers by famous bands, and even just driving around, along cliffs made of amplifiers, dodging giant swords sticking out the ground, makes you genuinely feel like you're inside an album.

Furthermore, guest appearances by Ozzy and Lemmy! What can go wrong?

A game specifically for fans of good old-fashioned heavy metal, with glorious locations, ridiculous action and a soundtrack that's simply perfect, definitely worth the cash. Go buy it!

reviewText:
Some games are made so that you can mindlessly mow down hordes of generic whatsits with your fat, noisy bullet-hose.
This is not one of them.
Some games are made so that you press A repeatedly in a series of menus so that you can watch your numbers go up every now and then.
This is not one of them.
Some games are really boring.
This is not one of them.

This game is an inspirational, madcap epic - in the proper sense of the word.  A single individual against vast and innumerable odds, conquering his way through adversity with nothing short of awe-inspiring trenchancy.  Weild thunder and lightning?  Check.  Throw fireworks?  Check.  Use a guitar as a magical death-array?  Bam, done.  Slaughter enemies with a souped-up motor-car forged by The Ozz of Metal?  Go ♥♥♥♥ing crazy.

This is a game that you do not soon forget.  This is a game where they've taken a masterpiece setting and given it a thick, heavy pulse, full of grit and power.  This is a game, ladies and gentlemen, that properly represents the spirit of Metal.
Should you thirst for blood and lightning, for power and amazement, for a five-star cast and white-knuckle writing, then spend your money on this fantastic game.  Play it, enjoy it, and cherish it.  It's well worth your time.

reviewText:
This game is just awesome: you've got blood, fire, noise and metal with a soft touch of Aetulia's singing. The game really makes you believe that there was an age of metal (which would be awesome, though) with demons, titans, Ormagoden himself and humans. If anyone would take this seriously, it might even become a religion (or at least another evolution theory) for some.

It's amazing that this game has been released with all the good ideas, I'd really want to see a sequel to it with the ability to make Eddie fly when roaming all around the map, although it would be easier to find secrets that way. The limits of the map aren't natural when talking about exploring the game, though: you hit an invisible wall at some point, it feels like the map is made out of many open-sided boxes. But all of these improvements would work even better with separate campaigns for every main character: Eddie, normal/drowned Ophelia(s, spoilers, sorry), Doviculus, that glam hairstyle wearing Lionwhyte, maybe even Rignarok with Succoria, and the future characters, if any. Even though it's far fetched, it would make a great addition to the game. And, of course, a longer story - I've beaten this game in 8 hours straight. Must. Have. More.

So in short, the game is already epic, some improvements would work in favor of the game (unless it becomes worse like what happens with some game series - the writers get carried away), the story pulls you into the game and holds you tight until you ultimately finish the game with every achievement unlocked. The songs are picked pretty well, too. In the name of  every metalhead in the world, Tim Schafer, please release a sequel!

reviewText:
This is an awesome tongue in cheek tribute to all that is Heavy Metal. In typical Double-Fine tradition the world is presented in an inventive manner, with a cast of interesting characters, voiced by an excellent line up.


Pros
- Awesome Metal soundtrack (and official score for that matter)
- Good sense of humour
- Fantastic selection of voice actors and Heavy Metal cameos
- World is fun to explore
- Reasonably good pacing (teaching and unlocking most abilities at a good rate)


Cons
- RTS sections may put you off if you are expecting purely hack-and-slash.
- It's not really obvious how much damage you are inflicting or is being done to your units (there are some visual hints, but in the heat of the RTS sections I wasn't really picking up on these)
- (RTS) Tanking isn't really an option, so most unit upgrading/advancing feels pointless (even on hardest difficulty)

I've had a blast playing this. I'd recommend this for Heavy Metal fans in particular for the soundtrack and whimsical take on the genre(s).  :)

reviewText:
First, I want to clarify my time played in Brutal Legend. The bulk of my playtime is from the Xbox 360 version, so while it looks like I haven't even beaten the tutorial, I did actually take a sick day when Brutal Legend came out on 360 many moons ago. I think I have played it about 1.5 times through.

I like to think of Brutal Legend in two different minds: the Gamer, and the Heavy Metal Fanatic.

The actual game part of Brutal Legend is rough around the edges. There are a lot of Double Fine firsts here, such as multiplayer and Real Time Strategy elements. I found the RTS battles to be very unsatisfying. I usually just made as many troops as I could, sent them somewhere, and then went somewhere else to fight solo. There is a bit of strategy in what composition of units is optimal, but its very loose, so its not like you can make really bad mistakes.

Controlling Eddie Riggs is usually solid, as is the driving of the Druid Plow. There were times where I got a little crazy in the Plow and got stuck on some rocks and had to restart from a checkpoint, but generally I could drive wild all the time.

And then there is the Heavy Metal Fanatic side to this game, where it absolutely blows away basically every game ever made. Every section of the game just feels like a classic album cover. It truly feels like a world that only exists in Heavy Metal. The soundtrack is absurdly good, and full of unusual tracks from familiar bands. As a lifelong fan of the genre, I still found some bands I had never heard before that I enjoyed. And the Druid Plow's roaring engine complements the songs very well. I spent a lot of time just crusing.

Plenty of cameos are in the game, both apperance and voice, such as Ozzy and Lemmy. The script is usually quite good, but some of the jokes might fly over the heads of people who aren't as invested in Heavy Metal as I am. Most of the writing isn't like that, but it definitely takes a different tone when you know the source material they are pulling from.

I would recommend this game to anybody who has any interest in Metal music. It was fun to hear music I had never heard before and enjoy it. Just treat Brutal Legend as a fantastic tribute to a rich and diverse music genre. Don't go in expecting to be blown away by game mechanics. It might get frustrating at times, but the sights and sounds are what makes this game one of my favorites.

reviewText: I picked this up on sale for about 80% off assuming it would be good for a laugh or two then something to move on from. Instead I was hit with engaging characters, an amazing compilation of various metal sound tracks, fun missions and a memorable story. Sure, Jack Black voicing the main character was fun to listen to, but everything in the game was just so wonderfully done aswell from beautiful bright and dark landscapes to even the little details of having rose bushes made out of rocker fists. I feel this game didn't get the credit it deserves around gamers. The only thing that I felt hindered my fun was the hunting questlines which were dry and only a little memorable because of Brian Posehn rocking a very cool NPC questgiver. I played about 16 hours in total for about 3 dollars and enjoyed almost every minute of it. Grab it if it goes on sale :)

reviewText: (Four horns for the metal; two for the game itself)\n\nThis is fantastic game for metal heads, primarily, for all the in-jokes and chuckle-worthy self awareness. Black's dialogue and delivery is priceless as is the fantastic writing by Mr. Schafer himself. The PC version is more than 'just a port', looking and moving far superior to the console editions. The controls are fantastic, specifically with a gamepad. The only issue I have with the game, really, is that combat can be far too simplistic and frantic to be as fun as one might imagine it would be. Also, once the game introduces RTS elements in the form of squads and minions, it goes from 'true metal' to 'nu-metal' in terms enjoyment. That being said, there is a great story here with an enjoyable cast of characters and satirical achetypes. The game overall is great fun, and exploration and a joy. It's a shame that it couldn't decide if it was an adventure game, beat 'em up or a strategy game.

reviewText:
If you're buying this game looking for a serious, intensely challenging and/or revolutionary game, keep the wallet shut. This game's big, dumb and ridiculous, and that's exactly where the joy in it lies.

It's easily accessible to just about anyone, controls are simplistic for the most part, but the RTS elements are a little challenging at first. The story in itself is pretty much exactly what you'd expect from a videogame combining Jack Black and Metal, and it's a great laugh.

The locations, however, are what make the game really stand out. All the major locations are based on real-life album covers by famous bands, and even just driving around, along cliffs made of amplifiers, dodging giant swords sticking out the ground, makes you genuinely feel like you're inside an album.

Furthermore, guest appearances by Ozzy and Lemmy! What can go wrong?

A game specifically for fans of good old-fashioned heavy metal, with glorious locations, ridiculous action and a soundtrack that's simply perfect, definitely worth the cash. Go buy it!

reviewText:
Impressive how someone can turn a simple theme such as an musical style (in this case Heavy Metal) into an epic experience so full of references.

Everything in the game dwells on the characteristics that compose Heavy Metal in such an spectacular way that even someone like me, who doesnt have the knowledge on the style is mesmerised by all its elements.

The story seems a little lackluster in the beginning but it picks up and the extras give it a shine showing a little unexpected lore.

The Mechanics develop little by little and are fun since the get-go but they get repetitive near the end.

The only part on it that didnt captivate me was on the strategy part since its quite simple and that kind of genre requires some complexity to really last.

The game has an awesome theme development, with an inspiring soundtrack for your epic journey & funny dialogues in the style that only Double Fine brings.

reviewText:
This game gets two thumbs up, not just one. If you do not wish to read a long, detailed review, know this; Brutal Legend is absolutely brilliant. It has a good story, fast paced gameplay, which combines action and some Real-Time Strategy elements, is semi-open world (more on this later) and has the most rocking soundtrack of any game in living memory.

So, what do you get if you purchase Brutal Legend. Firstly, you will find a crisp video introduction featuring Jack Black, introducing you to a record of such rarity, he forgot where it is. When he stumble upon and opens it, you are presented with the best menu system in any game. It is quality, and marks the start of what will become a quality game. After starting the game, you are thrust into the main story. Make no mistake, this game is story driven. It will present you with the illusion of choice, but, really, there is little need to play many of the side quests except to earn Favour of the Gods points, which you can spend on upgrades to your car. The story is suitably epic. I will not spoil anything suffice to say that you are a Roadie for a modern tween-metal band, just getting on with your thing, thinking back to the glory days of metal, when an accident calls you to action. After the carnage has cleared, you awake in a new land, one in which you can harness the power of metal to slay the bad guys. After this, you are tasked with freeing a people, helping with an uprising and vanquishing the oppressors of this world. The characters are excellent, many voiced by prolific figures in rock and metal - Jack Black, Rob Halford, Lita Ford, Ozzy Osbourne, Lemmy, etc. Each character is designed to be the cliche, but this is no bad thing. It adds to the humour of the game.
Your character, Eddie Riggs, is armed with a giant axe and a giant axe (this time of the guitar type). With one, you can bash the living daylights out of your opponents, with the other, you can call lightning strikes, small explosions or play solos. The solos are a great game dynamic. Use them to summon your car, raise relics that are used for varying purposes, or simply melt the faces off large groups of enemies. You also use them to capture fans in the RTS parts of the game.
This is where the game gets unique. Rather than simply bashing your way through hordes of enemies, you get presented with a battleground at various point in the game. You and your crew build a stage, as does the enemy. This is your base, if you will, and you must protect it. Geysers in the ground spew forth ghostly fans, which you have to capture to boost your fan points. These you can spend to upgrade your stage, your fighters and actually buy your units. The battles are fast paces and frantic, but very enjoyable, at least for a time. Luckilly, this part of the game is not overused. When it is used, it is in the right places, and builds tension. However, for me, there was perhaps one or two too many of these RTS bits. When the rest of the game tries hard to vary what it is doing, these are always a little bit samey, which is a shame. At least the setting changes each time.
I completed the game in a single sitting or about 7 hours. I played some of the secondary missions, but not all - I am not a completionist. However, for completionists, you will be happy to know that the main story is only about 50% of the game - there is still plenty to do. For the age of the game, the graphics are amazing. It easily holds up with today's games, mainly due to the art style, which is phenominal. It really is a good looking game.
Overall, I was thoroughly impressed. I bought the game a long time ago and never played it, but thought, hey
date: I may as well give it a go". Thank goodness I did
recommended: as it is now one of my favourite games of all time. It is humourous
hoursPlayed: with its tounge firmly in its cheek
voteText: but hell does it rock. Buy this! Buy this now!!!!!!"

reviewText:
Overview: Brütal Legend is a quirky third person game that mixes open world, action combat, and strategy into a Heavy Metal themed world.  You play as Eddie Riggs, voiced by and modeled to look like Jack Black, whos mission it is to liberate humanity from oppression.  The best word to describe this game is unique, the mesh of different gameplay styles and the manifestation of Heavy Metal into a video game really sets this game apart.

Pros: The coolest thing about this game is the Heavy Metal theme.  The world is literally Heavy Metal brought to life.  Trees are made of metal, spiders spin metal guitar strings, and giant engine parts strew the land.  The environment is well crafted and looks great.  The game has a good sense of humor and you will find yourself laughing at the characters and the situations that arise.  The story is decent and you can find things to do between story missions.

Cons: The first thing you will notice is that the combat is lacking.  It does not flow smoothly between enemies and the provided combos don't seem to do much.  Even though the Heavy Metal theme is the games best aspect, it is also a draw back.  If you do not like Heavy Metal, this game probably isn't for you.  All the music is metal and the characters embody all that is metal.  The mixing of action combat with strategy might be difficult for people to progress through the game.  The strategy portion is the most difficult aspect of the gameplay and requires more effort and planning.  For people who have experience in one genre but not the other, they will probably have a hard time.  That being said, the action combat is actually really easy.  Even playing on the hardest difficulty, I breezed through most of the game.  Lastly, the game is a little short, with the story lasting about 14 hours unless you are spending a lot time on side missions.

Conclusion: Brütal Legend is a unique experience that will keep you laughing at its quirkiness.  It's not a game for everyone, but if you like Heavy Metal and the idea of a world themed after it, you may enjoy this.  If you're looking for something with non-traditional gameplay and not expecting a masterpiece, give this a try.

Score: 8.3 / 10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Metalhead's Paradise.\nThe biggest project by Double Fine to date released on consoles with the help of EA and self-published 3 years later on PC, Brütal Legend is the ultimate videogame tribute to metal as a music genre. The game features stars like Jack Black and Ozzy Osbourne, absolutely kick-♥♥♥ soundtrack that can satisfy tastes of pretty much any true metal fan old and new (who said nu"?)
date: shines with great humour and takes place in a rich and creative open world that feels truly alive with real-time day and night cycle and variable weather.\nGameplay-wise it starts as an extremely fun slasher but halfway through turns itself into a somewhat hectic action-strategy which may turn many people off
recommended: but take your time to master its mechanics and you will find hours of entertainment within
hoursPlayed: which further extends into the game's multiplayer part.\nA must-have for every true metalhead regardless of their sub-genre preferences and just a fun open-world slasher / action-strategy game for everyone else."

reviewText:
Jack Black? Check
Many legendary rockstar apearances? Check
Decent combat and combos? Check
One of the best soundtracks that any game has ever had? M**HERf**KING CHECK!!

Honestly if youre a fan of Jack Black, his work as a musician or actor this game will please you from beginning to end. But being very very frank. What made this a very good game for me was not the great voice acting, or the massive world, or all the side missions that bring depth and color to this game, the great world that was created, or even the beautiful Ophelia... What makes this amazing is the most beautiful compilation of Rock ever to grace any game, even surpassing Ukelele Hero. Brütal Legend is a MUST buy for any fans of Jack Black, good Rock or heavy metal and a somewhat ludicrous story mixed in with humor.

Pros: Story, world, characters, music, humor

Cons: Combat gets a bit dull after a while (mixing it up with combos and special attacks changes this obviously.)

8/10

reviewText: I quite love this game. The graphics are decent, the gameplay is mostly okay, but the artstyle, writing and everything else are just phenomenal - especially voice acting and the music collection. If you are a fan of Metal or Rock, you will love this game, since every aspect of the game is just so well made that everything in the game is literally Metal. The only bad part of the game is the RTS-esque gameplay, which comes up a few times and this is a major downside in my opinion. It's not too often and it's not the main part of the gameplay, but it's in there and after all you do it for a few times and it takes it's time. My guess, around 7-10 times, but I could be wrong. Anything else is just really, seriously.\nIt is flawed, it is not perfect, but it's really original in its presentation - both sound and visuals. This game is not for everyone, but you can have a lot of fun with it.

reviewText: I've literally just started this and it's already the single most enjoyable game I've played since Timesplitters: Future Perfect. It even has an awesome as hell main menu. I cannot recommend this game enough, especially if you like either Jack Black or heavy metal. If you like both it will be a fundamental part of your game collection and cannot go another moment unpurchased. the gameplay is awesome so far, I mean who doesn't wanna dispatch of demons by shredding a few powerful licks or just straight up shredding them with your axe? (Same thing really) The humour is fantastic as one can expect from a game that features Jack Black, Lemmy Kilmister and Ozzy Osbourne. If I haven't sold you on it by now then it's a hopeless cause but If like me you've missed games that are just plain fun in the recent tsunami of games that take themselves too seriously then this is exactly what you're looking for. This or the Saints Row franchise. I know with only 40 minutes on record (currently) my opinion may seem invalid but play it and you'll understand why I feel I can write this review with a solid opinion after so little time.

reviewText: Best first thirty minutes game experience I've ever had, seriously - absolutely insane and hilarious. The beginning is pure fireworks in every respect. Unfortunatelly, the rest of the game does not quite live up to it, even though it's full of heavy metal madness - wonderfully primitive - just the way it has to be: Nice metal references and clichés that are exaggerated to such extend that you don't even care about them and just bang your head. Flaws: repetitiveness, lame side quests. Impressive: I'd never have believed that a genre-mix of 3rd-person-axe-wielding, guitar-powered magic-devastation, hotrod-racing and epic-battle-command would work out that smoothly. Great job! Anyway, it's a good game and a lot of fun - as soon as you've unchecked all Motörhead-tracks from the playlist, that is :P\nUh, I almost forgot: Controller is highly recommended - xbox-controller works great.

reviewText:
This game gets two thumbs up, not just one. If you do not wish to read a long, detailed review, know this; Brutal Legend is absolutely brilliant. It has a good story, fast paced gameplay, which combines action and some Real-Time Strategy elements, is semi-open world (more on this later) and has the most rocking soundtrack of any game in living memory.

So, what do you get if you purchase Brutal Legend. Firstly, you will find a crisp video introduction featuring Jack Black, introducing you to a record of such rarity, he forgot where it is. When he stumble upon and opens it, you are presented with the best menu system in any game. It is quality, and marks the start of what will become a quality game. After starting the game, you are thrust into the main story. Make no mistake, this game is story driven. It will present you with the illusion of choice, but, really, there is little need to play many of the side quests except to earn Favour of the Gods points, which you can spend on upgrades to your car. The story is suitably epic. I will not spoil anything suffice to say that you are a Roadie for a modern tween-metal band, just getting on with your thing, thinking back to the glory days of metal, when an accident calls you to action. After the carnage has cleared, you awake in a new land, one in which you can harness the power of metal to slay the bad guys. After this, you are tasked with freeing a people, helping with an uprising and vanquishing the oppressors of this world. The characters are excellent, many voiced by prolific figures in rock and metal - Jack Black, Rob Halford, Lita Ford, Ozzy Osbourne, Lemmy, etc. Each character is designed to be the cliche, but this is no bad thing. It adds to the humour of the game.
Your character, Eddie Riggs, is armed with a giant axe and a giant axe (this time of the guitar type). With one, you can bash the living daylights out of your opponents, with the other, you can call lightning strikes, small explosions or play solos. The solos are a great game dynamic. Use them to summon your car, raise relics that are used for varying purposes, or simply melt the faces off large groups of enemies. You also use them to capture fans in the RTS parts of the game.
This is where the game gets unique. Rather than simply bashing your way through hordes of enemies, you get presented with a battleground at various point in the game. You and your crew build a stage, as does the enemy. This is your base, if you will, and you must protect it. Geysers in the ground spew forth ghostly fans, which you have to capture to boost your fan points. These you can spend to upgrade your stage, your fighters and actually buy your units. The battles are fast paces and frantic, but very enjoyable, at least for a time. Luckilly, this part of the game is not overused. When it is used, it is in the right places, and builds tension. However, for me, there was perhaps one or two too many of these RTS bits. When the rest of the game tries hard to vary what it is doing, these are always a little bit samey, which is a shame. At least the setting changes each time.
I completed the game in a single sitting or about 7 hours. I played some of the secondary missions, but not all - I am not a completionist. However, for completionists, you will be happy to know that the main story is only about 50% of the game - there is still plenty to do. For the age of the game, the graphics are amazing. It easily holds up with today's games, mainly due to the art style, which is phenominal. It really is a good looking game.
Overall, I was thoroughly impressed. I bought the game a long time ago and never played it, but thought, hey
date: I may as well give it a go". Thank goodness I did
recommended: as it is now one of my favourite games of all time. It is humourous
hoursPlayed: with its tounge firmly in its cheek
voteText: but hell does it rock. Buy this! Buy this now!!!!!!"

reviewText: I've literally just started this and it's already the single most enjoyable game I've played since Timesplitters: Future Perfect. It even has an awesome as hell main menu. I cannot recommend this game enough, especially if you like either Jack Black or heavy metal. If you like both it will be a fundamental part of your game collection and cannot go another moment unpurchased. the gameplay is awesome so far, I mean who doesn't wanna dispatch of demons by shredding a few powerful licks or just straight up shredding them with your axe? (Same thing really) The humour is fantastic as one can expect from a game that features Jack Black, Lemmy Kilmister and Ozzy Osbourne. If I haven't sold you on it by now then it's a hopeless cause but If like me you've missed games that are just plain fun in the recent tsunami of games that take themselves too seriously then this is exactly what you're looking for. This or the Saints Row franchise. I know with only 40 minutes on record (currently) my opinion may seem invalid but play it and you'll understand why I feel I can write this review with a solid opinion after so little time.

reviewText:
I'm not really a fan of Slash games in general, and I'm not really a fan of metal in general. I am though, a big Double Fine fan, and they did not disappoint me in this one. mowing down loads of enemies is not that disappointing when it's not the only thing you do.

I really enjoyed how they turned some parts of the game into a little RTS, managing your army (one of the funniest things I've ever seen, tbh) while building merch stores and shredding away to mow down enemies... that's just silly, yet awesome.

The cameos are just so funny, Ozzy as the beholder of all metal is perfect, and Jack Black as the main character is not half bad, he actually managed to pull this hardcore badass that'll save the world through the power of metal.

To make a long story short, this game is worth it's price, tight graphics, amazing Soundtrack (that really fits in with the game) and great character designs... One of Double Fine's Finest.

reviewText:
The game concept is great and the story is pretty fun. The cutscenes and characters are great as well. The gameplay is a bit generic but has a bunch of unlockables thrown around a somewhat boring map, which will keep you entertained enough as you drive pretty much everywhere. Obviously the theme of the game is Heavy Metal and there is a lot of that in there. Some of the cameos are painful, but having a wide library of music to play while you drive around is pretty cool.

During the game, there are these really out of place RTS battles. It is a welcoming change of pace to the game, but gets really old really quick and seems shoehorned in. There is even a multiplayer version of it no one will play.

RTS shoehorns aside, this game is pretty good. The gameplay is mediocre but the cutscenes and overall look and feel of the game really did it for me.

reviewText:
Honestly I only wanted to play this game because Jack Black was the voice actor for Eddie Riggs.

Then here comes the gameplay, at first I thought that it's gonna be a hack and slash game but it turns out that it's not just that. In fact, I consider this game more of a strategy than an action game. The controls aren't that smooth but it'll do.

In conclusion, I enjoyed this game very much and think that you should try this game if you really love rock/metal song playing in the background.

reviewText: I played this game originally when it released in 2009 for the X360 and PS3. It was a weird hybrid of action adventure infused with RPG elements and RTS stage battles, tributing to metal music (actual metal music...) It was a mix-up of game genres that typically wouldn't work very well together. In Brutal Legend's case, the team at Double Fine pulled off a masterpiece. This game doesn't really have a place in any game genre, but it doesn't need to because it belongs into it's own category of weird quirky games what work exceptionally well. The first hour or so of the game, it seems like a typical action adventure open world game, until you get to doing your first stage battle... The game then becomes a hyperactive RTS for the battle sequences. Overall, this game is well worth the price, and it will be hard to put down once you step into the metal gods twisted and sickly awesome world.

reviewText: Brutal Legend is a game with identity issues. It can't seem to decide if it wants to be an open-world action-RPG, a real-time strategy game, or a driving simulator and due to that indecision none of those elements feel fully thought out or completed. The only thing that is thoroughly fleshed out is the Heavy Metal theme. There's sections that look like they were ripped right off of a Metal album cover, units that embody (or mock) fixtures of Metal culture, and a deep mythos that melds Norse mythology (the most Metal of all known mythologies) seamlessly with all that is Metal. Of all the shots Brutal Legend takes that just miss the mark, the commentary and the love of Metal is dead on. The game has the rare quality of producing lore that is instantly humorous but on a second look, is equally as capable of being taken seriously. That quality, and the fact the gameplay is switched up so often, makes it difficult to get too annoyed with its shortcomings. The familiar faces and voices of a couple stars in the world of Metal doesn't hurt either, even if they are overused to the point of parody.

reviewText:
3rd person, action, adventure game with open world feel.

Very funny game voiced by a lot of famous Rock / Metal music artists. Many popular Rock / Metal music tracks through out the game. Main character you play as is voiced by Jack Black, that also looks somewhat similar in game. Basically in this game, you try to help people with the power of Rock / Metal music.

A lot of melee hack and slash combat, with some fun combo moves and effects. Game has good but simple story, great humor, decent visuals, nice animation, great voice acting, average environments and really great selection of music. It's a simple but very fun experience, unless you don't really like Rock / Metal music.

reviewText: Not bad for a third person action game but much better titles exist. Darksiders 2 immediately comes to mind. This is still a fun game with pretty decent gameplay though. Being a fan of hardcore metal and deathcore, I despise the music in this game. I bought it for the gameplay though so it is tolerable. Jack Black does good voice work in this game and it is fun to run around killing things and doing missions. The graphics are below average but the game has good art design. Combat is a little janky but still works good enough. The game could have been optimized better as it gets a few stutters here and there but nothing that really detracts much from the core gameplay. Car handling pretty much blows. Controlling minions is easy and combat is pretty straight forward. The game may not have the depth or overall fun factor of much better third person action games but it doesn't take itself seriously it tries to have fun and crack a few jokes so it is decent for one play through.\n\n6/10 a good deal at $5 or less.

reviewText: I'm going to be brutally honest with you, brutal legend is an amazing with a unique design, fusing music (specifically metal/rock), real time strategy and action-rpg.  The balance is just right, and the world you explore is amazing and detailed, giving you lots of opportunities when you are not progressing the main storyline to explore and take on side tasks if you desire. The game's hero is voiced by Jack Black and he brings his signature humor to the game, coupled with other celebrity appearances lending to the atmosphere of the game. Returning to the gameplay, the combat is almost single hero based with squad control, and basic single base RTS elements which it executes well (very intuitive with controller). The story is something I'd rather not spoil, but it is characteristic of Metal, and Metal themed media, that being said, even if you as the gamer are not a fan of the genre there is still a rich world and character interactions/story elements that are applicable to all aspects of music and a solid gameplay experience which should definitely keep you involved. The only place where this game falls short, and I'm not alone in this sentiment, is near the end (spoiler free review of course), it seems like the game was going to have a decisive third act but instead it was concluded on the second act. Nobody really knows the reasoning behind this aside from probably the development team, but it left gamers wanting more even though it did still basically wrap up all the loose ends of the story. Regardless this game is a full recommendation to fans of metal/rock no all music, and those who enjoy a good action rpg. It is an accessible, quality experience which will leave you with many fond memories of it. Embrace your inner metal-head and get this game.

reviewText:
Provided that you like (or at least tolerate) all of the following:  Various forms of Metal music and all the imagery that comes with them, 3D Beat-em-ups, Driving, Exploration, RTS games, chatty NPCs, and the voices of Jack Black, Tim Curry, and Ozzie Osbourne... this may very well be your new favorite game EVER.  It's charming and imaginative, funny, and utterly awesome.

But if any one of those elements would be an absolute deal-breaker for you, well... you can't really avoid any one of them altogether, although I did manage to fudge through most of the campaign's RTS segments with a one-man-army approach; the car becomes really OP in single-player.

Oh yeah, there's also a competitive mode, in which you can play as the factions that were strictly enemy opponents in the single-player campaign, but you REALLY have to be into the RTS mechanics to stand a chance there.

reviewText: Suffers from the double-fine curse. It's a game with funny dialog, fantastic music, great atmosphere, brilliant voice acting, and unpleasant gameplay.\n\nLike psychonaughts, it is much more fun to watch than it is to play. True, this is much better than psychonaughts -- the camera isn't always fighting you for control, for example. However, the bizarre mix of RTS and third-person combat feels confused and isn't much fun. If you want the best experience from this, just buy the (awesome) soundtrack and watch the funniest clips on youtube. Actually playing the game is optional.

Pros:
— Awesome universe, beautifully crafted and immersive
— Pretty good graphics
— Killer soundtrack
— Great scenario, with depth and twists
— Delicious cameos from Lemmy, Ozzy, etc.

Cons:
— Frustrating controls (no jumping, no strafing, and worse: not enough responsivity...)
— Too much dialogue, and it doesn't work good (the same NPC sometimes repeats the same line 10 times in 30 seconds)
— Too much (useless) cutscenes, especially in the beginning
— The RTS part is tedious as balls. And I say tedious, not difficult, because it's just not fun.
— Way too often the game threw me into the domain of I DON'T KNOW WHAT THE HELL IS GOING ON AND I HAVE NO IDEA WHAT I'M DOING. That is not a good thing.
— Most objectives are absolutely unclear and the trial and error to figure out what the games wants you to do is a hassle.
— The fact that there is nothing on the screen (no health meter, no map... nothing) may be arty" but it doesn't help and makes the game even more confusing.

Conclusion: What would have made an absolutely awesome movie makes a game that is okay at best. The fact that the gameplay is a blend of various genres is nice
date: but not well done. The artistic part is AMAZING
recommended: but the gameplay is just not good.\n\n5/10."

reviewText: It's hard to review this game as it has many great ideas, but also many horrible ones. And sometimes even those great ideas are horribly executed. The game is a hybrid 3rd person action adventure with RTS elements with racing elements. Truth be told, I spent 3/4 of the game in Deuce, the beefed up car, mostly because the 3rd person combat and RTS elements are rather poorly executed. The game's story is quite an interesting one and cameos from many well known metal figures are rather funny and/or interesting. All in all if you like metal music, just buy the game. You will enjoy many many things while enduring the cumbersome parts. \m/ If you don't like metal music, or if you're just indifferent to it, there is nothing for you here. Nearly every aspect of the game lacks polish and it's not worth going through all the shortcomings to enjoy the nice story.

reviewText:
Brütal Legend is a fun action/adventure game with a lot of comedy in the World of Metal which is now been enslaved by a demon, and you Eddie Riggs, need to free it.
The game has a great atmosphere with excellent music and responsive combat system. Also the game manages to mix open world action with some strategic grand scale battles with bosses. Graphics and art design are also Brütal and appealing to look at.
Probably the only problem is that the AI sometimes plays it easy, while other times make it really hard for you, mostly on these strategic stage sessions. These battles therefore can be a little stiff sometimes and hard to beat. Issuing orders and keeping the battlefield together is also really hard in this view.
The side missions are fun, but after a while you will see that most of them are repeating quests and they are the same except for some.
The game is fairly long (around 12 hours) with (a my opinion) kinda lame ending. There is a multiplayer also, but without matchmaking, so you can pretty much just play with your friends.

Brütal Legend is a rare gem in the action genre and a very fun game to play. I would definitely recommend to metal/rock fans, or even those who are just looking for some fine action.

8/10 Awesome !
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is a wonderful mash up of the Action, RTS, driving, and Guiar hero genres. Soem it does better than others. If you are a fan of metal, speciafically classic metal (Black Sabath, Judas Priest) this game will speak to you. The action parts are smooth and the story line is decently knit together. There are some quests where you just feel you are on a fetch quest, yet most open world games have that feel at some point. Thegenre mashups do help keep the game feeling fresh as you near the end.
PROS: soundtrack, Genre mashup, Jack Black humor, metal guest stars, seemless transitions

CONS: Genre mashup, repetetive, slow parts may turn you off of the game

Clarification: Genre mashup can be good and bad, it is good because it keeps the game fresh, it is bad because the RTS sections, which are forced, are not that great. You can single handedly do most of them with out needing to even go into the unit build menus.

reviewText: One of the most artistically creative games I have seen hit from the 7th console generation. Everything in the game is a celebration of all things rock and metal, and as such, it has a ton of great music in it and personality and charm oozes out of this game's pores. I was really pleasantly surprise when Double Fine put in the effort themselves to get this originally PS3/360-exclusive and EA-published game onto the PC, and then even Mac and Linux, when they originally had no plan to do so, much like how they went back and gave Psychonauts a new shine on PC/Mac. It's a good port of a good, straightforward game, and I don't think it sold very well during its initial release, so major kudos to Double Fine for believing in their game and expanding it to reach new audiences. I thoroughly enjoyed this open-world hack-n-slashy journey, including those somewhat strange RTS-like parts you may have heard about. A truly inspired and fun, unforgettable game with a lot of heart and a brilliant vision.

For starters i am going to ignore the controls and will bring them up a little further down.

Ignoring the controls the game is brilliant one of the best soundtracks i've ever heard in a game, classic jack black humour amazing scenery and atmosphere i truly felt like i was in a mystical place of rock and roll.

FINALLY - THAT'S IT! This game just got EVERYTHING a good game needs. Zombie slayin' action with kick-♥♥♥-metal-riffs, firepowered nitro cars and Lemmy from Motörhead of course! Also there are some other secondary low priority reasons for buying it like a godlike storyline, awesome dialogs and laughing-my-♥♥♥-off videoscenes. It's like Zelda Ocarina of Time - just with a brutal heavy metal axe guitar instead of this childish ocarina. And the main reason for buying it? You can start a moshpit - anywhere!!!1 Yup, that's it. Really awesome, right?

Missing features that I wish to be implemented in the next version
- wall of death / circle pit attack
- switch between guitar, base and drumsticks
- more Jack Black (or Tenacious D? ultimate multiplayer fun WOOOOOOOHOOOOOO)

Thank you for this incredible game, I've waited all my life on. This will blow your mind. true story!

reviewText: One of my favorite games of all time. Sure it doesnt do anything brilliant mechanically (although generally well executed) and the radial menu is finicky at best with a mouse but the rest of the game is pure gold. The enviroments are utterly gorgeous (very metalized" e.g. everything is infused with stylized iconic heavy metal imagery)  The writing is mostly very well written and often hilarious. The stylized character models lend to expressive facial animations which add immense value to cutscenes. The RTS mechanic for major battles throughout the story is well executed albeit very basic for veterans of the RTS genre
date: but accessible for people who've never touched an RTS. And the soundtrack. The original game soundtrack is fantastic
recommended: add to that 100+ of the best metal songs ever made and you'll often find your head bobbing while you hack through demons."

reviewText:
If you can get this game below £10 It's worth it 100%
the game itself is set in a different universe where everything is inspired by heavy metal from the enemies to your allies even the map itself.
the story and charaters are interesting enough  and the humour is good(if you like the jack black type of humour).
The game itself is essentially an rpg with the main missions being a cross between a rts with the whole producing units, capturing resources and moving them units around with the addition of you yourself being able to fight in the combat.
throughout my playthrough I didn't come across any bugs or anything that ruined the game but I did find it to be way too easy as I managed to complete the game on it's hardest difficulty in only 7 hours (bear in mind I must've only died about 5 times in them hours)
There's a bunch of upgrades to the main character you can aquire in game aswell as for your main form of trainsport and lots of places to visit in the world itself.
So I hope this helps and once again if you come across this game being on sale either during a random sale or the summer and winter sale I would say buy it without a doubt like I did. Dont let it just sit there in your game libary with the other 100 or so games like I did as It was genuinly a treat to play.
