I am a dedicated metalhead and a former roadie and this game had me howlling with laughter from the moment I launched it. Total awesomeness and epic amounts of serious METAL! Buy this game! Gameplaywise it is reminds me of Overlord in an open world with a great soundtrack and also featuring a demon-hotrod.

The only real negative things so far is that controls are BAD with keyboard/mouse (but not nearly like Dead Space or any other crappy port of a console game) and a tendency to crash when tabbing in/out or on exit.

BRÜTAL! :D

reviewText:
If you can get this game below £10 It's worth it 100%
the game itself is set in a different universe where everything is inspired by heavy metal from the enemies to your allies even the map itself.
the story and charaters are interesting enough  and the humour is good(if you like the jack black type of humour).
The game itself is essentially an rpg with the main missions being a cross between a rts with the whole producing units, capturing resources and moving them units around with the addition of you yourself being able to fight in the combat.
throughout my playthrough I didn't come across any bugs or anything that ruined the game but I did find it to be way too easy as I managed to complete the game on it's hardest difficulty in only 7 hours (bear in mind I must've only died about 5 times in them hours)
There's a bunch of upgrades to the main character you can aquire in game aswell as for your main form of trainsport and lots of places to visit in the world itself.
So I hope this helps and once again if you come across this game being on sale either during a random sale or the summer and winter sale I would say buy it without a doubt like I did. Dont let it just sit there in your game libary with the other 100 or so games like I did as It was genuinly a treat to play.

reviewText: Well... it's a Heavy Metal themed Hack N' Slash RPG with Jack Black, Rob Halford, Lemmy Kilmister and Ozzy Osbourne, so what the hell do you think it's gonna be like?! Insanely f****** awesome is what it's like! Guitar solo power attacks, massive stage battles, mad races and a killer story. If you're a metal head, you HAVE to play this game, and if you're not a metal head, you HAVE to play this game. GET IT! It's one of the most awesome games ever made! reviewText: It's hard to review this game as it has many great ideas, but also many horrible ones. And sometimes even those great ideas are horribly executed. The game is a hybrid 3rd person action adventure with RTS elements with racing elements. Truth be told, I spent 3/4 of the game in Deuce, the beefed up car, mostly because the 3rd person combat and RTS elements are rather poorly executed. The game's story is quite an interesting one and cameos from many well known metal figures are rather funny and/or interesting. All in all if you like metal music, just buy the game. You will enjoy many many things while enduring the cumbersome parts. \m/ If you don't like metal music, or if you're just indifferent to it, there is nothing for you here. Nearly every aspect of the game lacks polish and it's not worth going through all the shortcomings to enjoy the nice story.

reviewText:
Ummmm. You know what. I don't like it. Maybe it's because I'm not a metal fan.

Gameplay-wise, it's a very generic action game with a rather empty open world, plus some combat combos. But that's about all. Tried to beat the game several times, everytime I couldn't stand the repetitiviness and yup, back in the shelf it goes.

In terms of soundscape this game does a decent job though, which I can't deny. Metal lovers will love the guitar riffs and overall metal themed BGMs and effects.The voice overs are very good also, just don't expect telltale-tier VOs and you will be fine.

I don't get it why so many people are recommending this. Perhaps the abundance of metal music references keep people interested. I really don't know.

reviewText:
As a preface: I'm not sure if my computer was meant to play this game.

I saw Jack Black in the opening of the game. He's hilarious. Surely the game has to be good.

And it was, up until I met this strange lady who the main character wanted too hard. I spent 4 hours on this game. 3 of them were at one part. I'm going to say up front that I'm not the best at Guitar Hero, but I play fighters, so timing buttons isn't terribly difficult. But yet, there was something going on. During the Guitar Solo portion of the game, the first one, even that only requires 4 different inputs, one of which is given to you for free, the timing wasn't right. At least, it wasn't right visually. I didn't think of doing it by ear because the sound should match up with the picture, right?

I don't know, but after look up stuff on the game, I didn't find many people with my issue, so I'm pretty sure it's got to be an issue with this computer. No big deal. It did make the game frustratingly unplayable, though. Oh, and the camera.

Don't get me started on the camera.

Then again, it could have just been visual lag again.

I don't know.

What I do know, though, is that the visual lag I had in this game made everything awful. The car responded to my inputs noticeably slowly and that made the first escape the bridge sequence awful. Along with every other car-related portion of the game. Along with every portion of the game. :/

reviewText:
+ The first 30 minutes of this game are awesome and funny.
+ The concept (living in a world of heavy metal) and how its executed is great.
+ You can tell they put a lot of love into designing the world.
+ Its an open world game (if you're into that).  Some of the collectibles in the game reveal the world history in a cool way.
+ Great voice talent and cameos.
+ THE BEST SOUNDTRACK FOR ANY GAME EVAR.

- Ok... the ending... it's one of those, Thats it?" endings.  Big let down.  I would have preferred them going with some old videogame trope like "No
date: I am the actual big bad guy behind it all
recommended: and now you have to fight me" then you turn into Ormagodden (the god in that world) and fight.  I would have been all for that.  This ending just kind of tainted the game for me.\n- Its an open world game
hoursPlayed: and it suffers from open world game tropes like repetive missions

the humor and pacing kind of fall flat.  I really feel like they could have done so much more with what they had here.

reviewText:
This game is a wonderful mash up of the Action, RTS, driving, and Guiar hero genres. Soem it does better than others. If you are a fan of metal, speciafically classic metal (Black Sabath, Judas Priest) this game will speak to you. The action parts are smooth and the story line is decently knit together. There are some quests where you just feel you are on a fetch quest, yet most open world games have that feel at some point. Thegenre mashups do help keep the game feeling fresh as you near the end.
PROS: soundtrack, Genre mashup, Jack Black humor, metal guest stars, seemless transitions

CONS: Genre mashup, repetetive, slow parts may turn you off of the game

Clarification: Genre mashup can be good and bad, it is good because it keeps the game fresh, it is bad because the RTS sections, which are forced, are not that great. You can single handedly do most of them with out needing to even go into the unit build menus.

reviewText:
I love Jack Black and everything he does. This game basically makes him the badass we all know he is, and lets you play that awesome character. The game is visually stunning, always picking the best view when you are idle. The soundtrack is BOSS, but, being Jack Black he made sure it would be.

The story, while a little bit cliche it would seem at times, is very entertaining and enjoyable. The combat however, is kind of repetetive at times to me, but still enjoyable with the mix of the guitar and the solos you can play. Jack Black playing the voice of the main character makes this game golden to me, and the suprise appearance of several other famous people makes it even better.

Overall I give this a 9/10 and would recommend this game to anyone looking for a good time. The derpy multiplayer is the only thing I really don't like about the game.

*EDIT*

to "the badass we know he is""

reviewText: One of the biggest points of this game is Heavy Metal and its imagery: Long-haired head bangers (with comically -unless you are a F1 pilot- sized necks), cool and sexy (In the eighties sense of sexy) biker girls, huge metal-themed statues bursting out of the ground, giganitc anvils with lava rives flowing, riffs, demons, epic battles, motorcycles speeding, and beer and horns everywhere. Is one of those games made by someone who enjoyed the medium it references and which grow in it. This is not a let's push some random generic references to heavy metal" (as so many games have done before with the eighties)
date: but a truly unique and well crafted journey through the perspective of actual metal fans of what the "Land of Metal" is.\n\nThus
recommended: if you know who Rob Halford is

reviewText:
Brütal Legend wants to be an ode to metal while being a fun game to play. At times it feels like the world collide good enough to be enjoyable, but as a game it doesn't work as well as it should.

The Good:
· Introduces gamers to metal and vice versa. If you're a fan of both, you will love this for sure.
· Great voice acting, including Jack Black among others.
· Creative environmental design...

The Bad:
· ... but the world itself feels flat and empty. Everything metal-esque is squeezed together in a little enivorment or area, but everything around that feels like a flat world with some stones here and there. It's an open world that doesn't need to be there, but one that exists simply to boost the scale and to keep you busy while going from A to B.
· Even though it's sweet to melt the faces of headbangers, the combat feels dull, repetetive and generally useless. There are basic axe-swinging attacks, then there's thunder and lightning to damage your enemies from a small distance. Besides that and some special guiter solo's, that's it.
· The enemies have no health bar and neither do you. It feels like you're just mashing buttons to see which one of you drops dead first. Your screen will start flashing if you're nearing death, but by that time it's either too late for you to flee away and keep some distance for a few seconds to do it over again. Some people say the combat is difficult, but I say there isn't enough information given on your screen to know just what you're doing.
· The story, albeit filled with iconic characters from the metal world, is dull and uninterresting. The familiar faces are the only reasons to sit through it until the very end.

The Ugly:
· The game isn't very pretty, but good enough to do the job. Nothing too dated, nothing too superb, just okay. The character models and filled environments are a clever mix between fantasy and rock that helps to make Brütal Legend a little bit more interresting.

Final verdict:
If you're a metal fan and ejoy the occasional video game, definately get this. If you're the other way around, like myself, then don't. It's 75% metal and 25% game, and Double Fine should have taken another direction with Brütal Legend. It's bigger than it needs to be, but not figuratively big enough to fit in all the potential.
5/10

reviewText:
Update:
Thumbs down.

After a dozen hours of play, technical issues and repetitive mini-games have killed my interest. I want to love this game for the theme and the aesthetic, but it just doesn't play well. The biggest problem was controller lag - there's a small but serious delay between the time that I push a button, and the time that the game responds. I've found posts from several people who also suffered from controller lag, tried their solutions, but nothing worked for me. This takes most of the fun out of the action sequences. Unfortunately, even if I'd found a solution to the lag, I think the repetitive mini-quests were just too much. How many times can I enjoy beating up the same cloned goon squad? Several. More than one.But not nearly so many times as the game seems to require.

Original review:
Thumbs up.

If you like Jack Black or Tenacious D, then you'll like this game. If not, then you probably won't.

As a fan of Tenacious D,  the style and theme of this game totally do it for me. Ever wanted to see what Rodin would do if he'd been a rocker? Then take a short hike to the guitar mountain overlook, where you can admire a gigantic slab of rock, sculpted by the Titans into the shape of pair of hands holding a guitar. Unfortunately, the gameplay is medicre, seemingly unfinished, with many of the missions being awkward or unclear. For example, there are several side-missions involving base-defense. The key to success is getting out in front of tne enemy. Unfortunately, despite cries of the enemy is coming!" and "they're behind you!" the attacking forces are often hidden by the landscape until just before they reach your base
date: which means it's hard to see them in time. If there'd just been a HUD arrow
recommended: something to point out the direction of new attackers
hoursPlayed: these missions would have been far more fun."

reviewText:
Pros:
- Well written/good humor
- Good voice acting. Features Jack Black, the gay front man from Judas Priest, and Sharon Osbourne's husband.
- The RTS/Action hyrid is sort of interesting.
- Cool world to explore.
- Nice cartoonish art style.

Cons:
- Unoptimised for the PC platform.
- Really short single player campaign (expect maybe around 5 hours). It's obvious that it was rushed.
- The combat is shallow and boring.
- There are two things to do in the world: gather collectibles and do side missions, and the side missions are bad.
- We're on the PC, so why are we limited to console style RTS controls?

Final Thoughts/ Notes:
- The ideal way to get the most out of this game is in multiplayer, granted if there are any people left playing it.
- The game is too ambitious. It fails at being an action and open-world game and is mediocre at being an RTS.

reviewText:
Brutal Legend is an Open World Action-Adventure-Hack 'n' Slash-Real Time Strategy Mix, and a pretty damn good one too.

You take the role of Eddie Riggs, a Roadie for many super awesome Heavy Metal bands, who ends up being the Roadie for a terrible modern pop tween fake metal band. Because of their carelessness, Eddie ends up dieing on stage. As he dies, his blood awakens the almighty Metal Beast which takes him back in time into the Age Of Metal to fulfill his prophecy of saving humanity from slavery and demons, while teaching them how to harness the power of Metal.

All aspects of the game are fairly well done, suprisingly simple yet enjoyable (though this is not the most popular opinion). As you do missions, you unlock more combat moves, guitar solos (summon your car, buff friendlies, etc...), side missions (a good variety of them), vehicle customization (did someone say mounted machine guns?), etc...

There's a lot of collectables, hidden secrets, legends, and lore to be discovered. Lots of Metal references and Humor, you'll laugh a lot.

The game comes with full controller support as well, and is the recommended device for play.

And the best thing about the game, the soundtrack, which you should check out for yourself ;) Have fun!

All in all, the best, if not perfect tribute to Rock 'n' Roll and Heavy Metal!

reviewText:
TLDR – Brutal Legend is a third person hack / slash game with some simple rhythm elements and a sprawling single player campaign. There’s a lot of humor to be found, probably due to the lead character being played by comedian Jack Black. It’s also got a lot of foul language, so be warned if that kind of thing offends your sensibilities (you get the option to add censors).

In the story, you play Eddie Riggs, a heavy metal music “roadie” whose job it is to follow rock stars around fixing things and setting everything up to make the band look awesome while staying out of the spotlight himself. Through a mystical event, you are cast into the distant past (The Age of Metal) ruled by a demon named Doviculus, and inhabited mostly by monstrous creatures. The whole game has a heavy metal music theme, including rock concert battles, playing music to cast spells (kind of like songs in Ocarina of Time), and a lot of cameo appearances by famous rock musicians.

Most of the gameplay is straightforward third person hack slash where you use your trusty axe and just swing until the enemy is dead (you can buy more special attacks later on). You also have a magic guitar to play songs for special effects, and as the story progresses you learn more and more songs to play. You also spend a lot of time driving around the open world in a car that you can summon (one of the first songs you learn). Like with most open world games, this means that the map is filled with optional missions and racing minigames, as well as artifacts that you can find for “fire tributes.” Fire tributes are the “money” of the game, and despite the game playing like an RPG, you don’t level up or get experience when fighting. You acquire the fire tributes and spend them on power ups and cosmetics for your character. One note that I’ll make is that a lot of the purchasable items are unlocked as the main story progresses, so don’t bother doing all the missions and hunting down collectibles too early in the game, since you won’t be able to buy much anyways until later on.

Pros:
+Despite not having the greatest graphics, it is clear that the game developers spent a lot of time on the scenery and overall game world. The main characters may look cartoony, but the otherworldly environment is great. If you’ve played Just Cause 2, you should know what that’s like (gameplay graphics better than cutscene graphics). If you enjoy rock music, you’ll be in for a treat as well. Driving along with the soundtrack is pretty fun.
+The game’s story is engaging and well written. Since the game world is so different from our own, the writers were free to come up with some interesting villains and history. Maybe you don’t like Jack Black’s style of comedy, but I thought it worked well with this particular game. He’s probably better known for childish humor/movies, but Brutal Legend has some mature themes.

Cons:
-As with many games of this type (open-world) there are a huge number of collectibles to be found and if you’re like me you probably don’t want to go out of your way searching for them after the game’s story is over. It turns out that you won’t have enough money to buy all the upgrades unless you hunt down most of the collectibles. There’s no easy way to do it either, even with an online guide because the game’s world map is kind of weak.
-One weird thing I noticed is that the game never actually tells you how to unlock some of these collectibles (using fire spells or thunder clap skills). I had to look it up online. This is a minor gripe though, since most collectibles just give you some fire tributes to spend. I was able to beat the game my first playthrough without buying much. The majority of purchasable items are cosmetic.

Overall, if you liked action adventure games such as Darksiders, but thought they would be better with more humor and less hardcore fighting, you may enjoy Brutal Legend. The game doesn’t take itself seriously, and the silly ways that rock music is woven into the story/gameplay will likely bring an occasional smile to your face.

reviewText:
Tim Schfer the Mastermind behind the cult hit classic Psychonaut did it again with another Double Fine Masterpiece. Brutal Legend.

This game has nearly everything a Heavy Metal follower would enjoy. It has Metal. It has rock star cameos everywhere, it has action, drama, Real Time Strategy, Music, comedy and such a compelling storyline that you would go deeper and deeper to learn everything about the world of Brutal Legend.

Why should you NOT get this Amazing work of Art? To put it straight you would be amazed by such detail and art that was put into this game to cater to a wide range of Rock enthusists.  To date this game has one of the most Licensed Metal/Rock Songs to date in this EA title. Sure EA as a company is pretty bad but Double Fine has talent that is not to be overlooked.
Buy at full price and you will not be regretting it.
Buy it at sales and you would be getting a treat for how massive it is!

If you enjoy Real Time Strategy, then Stage battles are definately quite an attracting part of it.

One gripe I do have though......How come only in the Stage Battles that you are only able to fly while on the Map you cannot? I guess it has to do with glitches/exploits I suppose. Nevertheless. Very graphic Heavy and intense you best have a PC strong enough with enough of processing power to run it.

Best First purchase on Steam that I never regretted. Thank you DoubleFine for such an amazing title!

reviewText: While the game awesome on the paper, it would only take 10 minutes to realize how poorly ported and broken it is.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Really, really great concept and a good story. This game is funny. And I like heavy metal quite much. Therefore, I really wanted to like this game.

BUT the controls are untolerable, especially with the car. It's not just me. Every negative review on the Store page mentions the same problem: controls.

I also find the camera distance and rotation problematic while driving the vehicles. Also, the game badly communicates the objectives or the means to achieve them. Only if you are doing something wrong for a while, a hint appears. Why not mention what and how to do something in the beginning? Why I have to keep guessing? Sometimes, I achieve victory right away, sometimes I need to try few more times. Either way I don't know what I did right or wrong. Things just happen in this game. The game has no mini-map, therefore I need to check the global map all the time. The game has no healthbar, therefore I don't know, how much health I've left. What's even worse: the game poorly communicates, whether you've received damage or gave damage. Also, it's hard to distinguish between friendly units and enemy units. For every friendly unit you have a matching enemy unit, who looks almost the same. The minor differences are noticeable only from a close distance. Also, the heavy emphasis on guitar solos doesn't make things any more convenient (you need to press a certain button combination during the solos and you are vulnerable to attacks for a few seconds before the solo is through).

Real-time strategy, racing, adventure, hack-n-slash - this game has mixed so many elements, but none of them is done properly.
The game has a good soundtrack and story and that's about it. Everything else is just chaos happening between the cutscenes. Therefore, I cannot recommend this game. The gameplay is torment.

But I do recommend to watch the cutscenes on YouTube. If you perceive Brutal Legend as a cartoon, it's great, especially, if you know a bit about the history of metal and hard rock music.

My overall rating: 6/10

reviewText:
Urgh.
Excellent job on the humour, nice enough graphics, stupid plot but then that's part of the charm.

But then.. The game play begins to suck. It's the uncomfortable blend of 3rd person view, guitar riffs & directing troops as an RTS that kills it. I just didn't want to be bothered with the larger battles, it's just a chore of dealing with the fact you need to be near troops to direct them, but you need to be in the air to get an overview, then you need to keep landing and playing riffs all the time. It probably sounds ok, but it just feels clunky and tedious to play.

Press tab to do this, Q to do those, 1 to 4 to do those, F to fly and land, don't forget your mouse combo's in fights .. pfft.

It's difficulty is fairly low, so even with the tortured interface you will probably win the fights, but it somehow isn't fun.

You might like it, it's not horribly horrible, just annoyingly tedious. Maybe controller based folk find it easier. It's a pain on PC keyboard & mouse though.

Sad face. It started with such a lot of promise as well.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: There is something weird about this game, it really makes you *want* to like it. It has a fun story, characters and setting and if you can  get it cheap (I picked it up in a humble bundle) it's probably worth a play through. The problem is it's also a bit crap. It tries to be an epic hack and slash adventure, a driving game, an rts, and a teeny bit of rhythm game thrown in for good measure... and in the end it means that it does none of these things particularly well. The UI occasionally breaks and basic touches that would have made certain things so much more livable and which are present in their other games... just weren't there. If you just want to play through, it's a shortish varied game working on the basis that stuff is awesome and you should come along for the ride. If you're looking for something more in depth, there are better options out there.

reviewText:
Short version: Good writing, bad controls, and buggy. Get for a console, or avoid entirely.

Long version: Brutal Legend is a well written game with a clever spin on the usual hero's journey story arc, with a self-aware sense of humor that makes even some of the failures funny. And that's the good news.

Bad news is that the gameplay itself is quite bad. First, you'd best have a controller, because Keyboard/mouse is basically impossible (Even the tutorial is for controller). Moving and attacking are sluggish, you fight the camera more than most enemies, trying to drive is a joke (and don't even think about racing), and the graphics will chuck often, even on a high-end PC.

And here's the real kicker. It's unplayable on high-end PCs. There's a bug that crashes when the game clashes with many graphics cards, most of them fairly good. The fix seems to be to UNDERclock your card/system. Yeah, no. I shouldn't need to make my PC worse to play a game. And at this point, there's pretty much no chance of a bug fix for it.

With the bug aside, it's a mediocre game that deserved better than what it got. 6.5/10 for the writing and style, but major points lost for the gameplay itself. And then the bugs just add to it. Get it for a console if you really still want this game. The PC version is just another lazy port.
